A great complex vinous beer.
Well.. it looks good, but unfortunately it smells like subdued bile and tastes like its past its "good by" date.

330 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet (bottled July 2011).  Murky brown pour with a foamy off-white head.  Aroma of light toffee and Belgian candi sugar mostly with nothing else really standing out.  In fact, the aroma is quite muted and gives little indication as to what this one will taste like.  The flavor is lightly tart but offers plenty of malt sweetness that helps to balance overall.  Again, nothing jumps out at you but that does not mean this is an average beer.  It is a fantastic Belgian strong ale.

(33 cl)  Une fine couche mousseuse se dépose sur un liquide à la robe profondément rouge.  Le nez est superbe : les malts dégagent une certaine douceur et une complexité étonnante, les prunes et les raisins ont un profil vineux, les cerises libèrent un parfum suret, les oranges sanguines se révèlent tandis que lalcool demeure un grand mystère.  Les saveurs quoffre cette grande dame sétablissent avec solidité et grand équilibre : les notes douces côtoient les notes surettes tandis que lalcool se transforme en fleurs et en poivre blanc.  En bouche, le liquide est habilement construit, porté par des bulles élégantes et texturé avec délicatesse et raffinement.  La finale est un concerto de notes surettes et douces avec des cerises éclatantes et sans aucun doute touchées par le sublime.
Donkerbruin met matige lichte kraag. Geur cassis. Smaak cassis, overrijp fruit, waarbij de nadruk wel erg op de cassis ligt. Ik vind het een tegenvaller en begrijp de hoge waarderingen niet zo.

De Dolle
Oerbier
Deep hazy brown with a thick tan head and good retention. Aroma is boozy with a thick maltiness and a funky spice note. Seems to have a lot of wine on the nose (barrel)
Flavor is wine like with a smooth malt character. Raisins and bubbles with  more of the red wine tartness. Not overpowering, but definitely there.

Mahognyfärgad öl med livligt julmustliknande skum. Doft av jäst, rostad malt och bränt socker. Smaken är komplex och lite spretig. Ger en torr känsla i munnen inte olikt ett torrt mousserande vin. Alkoholsötma, mandlar och torkad frukt. Skulle gärna smaka den lagrad då smakerna satt sig.

Bottle 33cl. Dark brown colour with beige, persistent and creamy head. Good lacing. Aroma is nutty, sweet, caramel, brown sugar, with alcoholic hints, also toasted mast are present. Flavour is sweet and toasty. Final is alcoholic with sweet hints. Fruits are present, no bittery. Moderate carbonation, full body.

Bottle.  Pour is deep reddish brown with a medium brown head.  Head is large and lingers.  Aroma is burnt sugar, molasses, sweet over-ripe banana, brandy, and toffee malt.  I hope the flavor is less sweet than the aroma.  Flavor is deeper and richer than aroma with notes of deep toffee malt, light hints of hop, brandy soaked fruit, brown sugar sweetness, and a faint champagne-like dryness.  The finish is long with hints of burnt sugar and faint roasted malt.  An aggressive beer and a little messy.  Not boring.

Bottle @ Head of Steam, Durham 081011
Reddish brown, hazy yeast, white head.
Complex aroma of fruit, vinous, dark malts, sherry and port aromsa.
Flavour - Complex and enigmatic - dark malts, roasted malt, dark fruits, port, sherry.
High carb. Palate - as main flavour with a hint of sourness. Rich malty fruity finish.
Overall - puzzling but very good. Need to try this one again and do the review properly, but this was the best I could come up with at the time.

Over-carbonated, took two minutes to relieve additional CO2 to prevent gushing! Took another three to pour it properly. That aside foamy cream head with ruby tinged brown body. Tropical pineapple aroma from the yeast. Rich sweet initial malt and pineapple with a strong alcoholic finish. Medium bodies with gentle carbonation. Definitely a sipping beer.

33cl bottle. Pours opaque black to plum in olour with a nice generous head a good amount of which hangs around. The nose is quite Christmasy - dried fruits or more precisely, whole fruit cooked in a cake, plump but sweet in flavour. There is also some soft, aromatic spice, maybe nutmeg. The taste has concentrated plums, black cherries and something on the edge of dark chocolate but not quite there. Theres also a little liquorice and cinammon this time. The palate has a very big structure, a big creamy middle texture and a clean, tangy finish. Overall, this ticks all the boxes for a big dark Belgian Ale.
Nose is cranberry, caramel, meat, weak raisin, feel is mediumweak, carb is heavy, taste is dried fruit (cranberry dominates), sweet, thin alcohol, mediumweak hops finish,

P: 3/5. hazy medium brown.  good amount of lightly-tan head, supported by good carbonation.  recedes by about half in a few minutes, no lacing. 

A: 4/5. boozy.  sweet. caramel.  raisin.

F: 8/10.  rich.  sweet.  caramel.  malt.  slightly sour pitted fruit.  some alcohol, but not strong.

M: 4/5.  slightly prickly carbonation, but lighter in the mouth than the flavor would lead you to expect.

O: 8/10.  very nice.
bottle, pour is a bit dark, lots of dark fruits in the taste and aroma, the beer is a bit dry and a light bitterness. good offering

Deep amber chestnut pour thin layer of creamy beige head nice sticky lacing ... aroma is of dark fruits but mostly caramel and roasted malts .... taste is of caramel, lightly roasted and chocolate malts, fruity malts more like darker fruits with a spicy and little abv to the finish .... dry malty and little booze in the finish ... an awesome brew smooth and creamy mouthfeel with a nice touch of spice
Poured a beautiful brown-ish color. Smelled like malts and fruit. The taste was fairly complex with an interesting finish.

Bottle at home from Great Grog. Pours a deep red with a brownish head. Aroma is spicy, earthy, quite sweet, boozy. Taste matches it - rich, spicy, with caramel, dark fruits/raisins. Nice warming alcohol, and a surprising amount of carbonation. Very nice indeed.

Light but very strong, potent, complex and fruity. The aroma is sweet of malts, fruit and alcohol. The flavor is a strong with a sweet undertone of fruit accompanied by alcohol throughout. Theres a lot going on, its good.

Pours a deep dark reddish brown with a brown head that stuck around till finish.  Aroma is earthy, yeasty, dark fruits and spice.  Taste is spicey sweet with the dark fruit coming through on the finish.  Not much warming on the finish for 9%. Medium mouthfeel with oily smooth texture. Excellent
Brown body, khaki head. Beer has nice sweetness and winey fruitiness compined with sturdy malts and some sourness. Alcohol is well hidden. I liked this a lot.
Bottle. Poured deep brown with small head. Aroma and flavour is mostly of belgian yeast, sugar, dark fruits. Very well done.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2011 33cl bottle. Poured in a Chimay glass, Dark brown with not too much head. Berries and little alcohol on the smell. Taste of raisins, candy and some alcohol, with a nice finish. Great body

Draft at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Very dark amber/brown with a small head that quickly disappears. Aroma is caramel, and very malty. Taste is bit fruitcakey, bit of treacle with lingering sweetness. Nice and full bodied. Class beer.

Pours a dark amber color with tan head. Aromas from yeast, spice,  slightly earthy tone, with caramel. On my first taste, I was surprised by the amount of carbonation. Medium/light body. Great sweetness of caramel, slight tart/sour and spice finish. The heat from alcohol (9%) is somewhat hidden and smooth. Interesting beer, hits the front of the tongue with carbonation /sweetness, moves to the middle with a sour hint, then back of tongue with the spice and finishes up with slow throat heat. Nice little symphony.
Aroma is yeasty, earth and spicy. Taste is spicy, caramel, burnt sugar, some dry fruits and a dry finish.

Bottle @ Home. Pours dark amber with a huge dense white head. Aroma of roasted malt, bread, light caramel, sour grapes / cherries. Taste is sweet malt, bread, hints of yeast, cherries, light hops. Medium body, soft carbonation, dry and slighlty sour finish. 130811

Al meu entendre una de les grans cerveses negres de Bèlgica, amb cos vinós i aroma canviant. Una joia que aguata el pas del temps sense cap mena de problema. Només igualada per la seva germana gran envellida en bótes de roure. Ningú se lhauria de perdre. Complexitat i satisfacció en un got de vidre.

Purchased while on vacation in Oregon at Belmont Station in Portland.  My bottle stated 9.5%ABV.  330mL bottle poured murky brown with red highlights.  Head is immense settling slowly to lace.  Aroma is of caramel and yeast.  Flavour is sweet malty with mild bitter hops in the finish.  Carbonation causes intense mouthfeel.  Body is adequate.
Nice dark brown / dark red color, average smell, fair taste. Decent carbonation and medium body.

Was hoping to be 1000th rating.  Oh well.  Bottle, rather fresh I think, at Toronado, SD.  Big fuzzy mouth that explodes.  I liked the feel of it with the overall beer experience.  Enjoyed taking a lot of time with the glassfull.  Big sweet malty with a light vinegar hint.  Really nice beer.  I definitely need to get a couple to lay down for a year or three.

Tasted on 7/27/11 from a 330mL bottle purchased at West Lakeview Liquors, not bottle date to be found.  Pours cloudy, dark burnt orange with a massive, foamy beige, pink-tinted head, that slowly recedes to rocky, thick lace, leaving a bit of residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is full of caramel and bread malt, but still very dry, along with some almost vinous fruity esthers, and spicy Belgian yeast.  The flavor is fruity and vinous up front, moving to the malty caramel and bread, a hint of cola, and spicy Belgian yeast.  The body is full with lively, very stinging, carbonation and a long fruity vinous, and spicy Belgian yeast finish, with some alcohol heat warming my belly.
Splendida belgian strong ale, targata de dolle, spesso la bevo da un caro amico in una taverna qua vicino. Gran bere signori...

330ml bottle. Clear, deep copper pour with three fingers of tan head that leaves a ton of lace. Very vinous on the nose with some spice and yeast and a whiskey-esque maltiness. Lots of spice and licorice on the palate with poorly masked alcohol that burns a little.
Pours ruby red, with a thick off-white head.  Aroma of yeast and anise.  Mature caramel background.  Nice body, aided by the fine carbonation.  Delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2013 Bottle of the 2010. Colour is a hazy reddish-brown with a good sized pale head. Aroma is a of fresh strawberries and caramel. Has a creamy texture and a good blend of sweet and sour flavours with a hint of bitter that lingers on finish - sour cherries, pink grapefruit and brown sugar. Quite enjoyable and I suspect it will age nicely.

1987 Vintage (Tasted on Oct 4th, 2013)
Tried a sample of the 1987 vintage thanks to a kind soul. Ruby brown, relatively clear, lightly carbonated, decent pale head. Aroma is honey, raisins, mushrooms, prunes, nutmeg. Full bodied, syrupy mouthfeel, extremely complex on the palate, fruity and sweet with some earthy notes and a hint of sour hidden in the background. Taste is prunes, cherries, raisins, over-ripe strawberries, sour plums, balsamic reduction. So smooth and complex.

A 9, L 4, T 9, P 5, O 19 => 4.6

Shared bottle at local tasting, thanks to Abemorsten.Pours hazy mahogany with no head at all. Aroma is sour and acidic. Taste is moderate sweet fruits, good malty underneath, maybe this improves with some cellaring.
UPDATED: NOV 3, 2014 (Bottle)I broke a brand new  Chimay goblets virginity  with this and it resembled  a Chimay blue . im gonna re8 this its better than my piss weak score offered

08.07.2011. 0,33l Bottle. Vinmonopolet Bergen - Valkendorfsgaten. Dark brown colour with white head. This beer is very lively carbonated. When pouring there is almost only foam in the bottle. But it gets better and this is a very good beer! Strong malty body with strong alcohol. There is also some malty sweetness and some sharp bitterness.
Iced tea color; thick frothy short-lived tan head. Lots of raisin, cherry, etc. Boozy bitterness found in abbey quads. Rather overcarbonated.

6/10/11. 11.2oz bottle. Slightly cloudy red/brown pour with a nice, fluffy tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, molasses, and brown sugar. Slightly tart flavor with oak and vinegar on top of chocolate, caramel, and more. Nice!
Wonderful beer.  Definitly among the best Belgians Ive had.  Love the aftertaste, a long enjoyable ride.  Had it a couple times at Cafe Bastille in Taipei from bottle
I dont really like this beer. The colour is the best thing about it. I dont like the smell and taste. Finished this one quite quickly and didnt take too many notes.
Bottle. Color dark red with big creamy head. Aroma sweet, spicy, honey, caramel. Taste sweet, caramel, fruits, spicy, alcohol.

Bottle. Ruby with a huge, creamy tan head. 
Aroma: cherries, raisins, perhaps port, candy.
Taste: candy, raisins, cherries, sweet but also tart, wine gums, some toffee, grassy, medium bitter, warming alcohol.
Full-bodied, medium high carbonation.

Dark orange/light brown body with a huge white head. Strong sweet aroma with spices, honey and caramel. Very full palate. Warming sweet flavour, malty caramel, alcohol, spices. Quite sweet and heavy. Very good nonetheless.

Oerbier on väriltään punertavan ruskea. Vaahto puolestaan on lähes valkoinen ja runsas. Tuoksussa on kypsää hedelmäisyyttä, viinimäisyyttä ja toffeeta. Maustakin tulee mieleen punaviinimäinen hedelmäisyys. Olut on myös hieman mausteinen ja hapan. Rungoltaan tämä on jonkin verran kevyt. Kyllä minä tämän hyväksyn.

Appearance: rich polished mahoganies. Creamy white head fades into a smooth thin film. Partial lace. Hint of chill haze; unfiltered.

Nose: raisins, plums, figs, peaty, smoky, oaky. Single-malt qualities. Red apple skins and cinnamon  baked apple pie crust. Sherried plums. Date stones, black cherries with stones. Dried dark fruits. Lovely.

Palate: wow. Hit of spice, oak, red and purple grapes. Clean flow of flavors. Spice tickles along the edges. Grabs middle of tongue and doesnt let go. Apples, plums, prunes, dates, and figs simmered long and slow in the finest of single-malts. Juniper in the finish. Starts to dry middle of tongue along with lingering warmth in middle of throat. Port. Plum skins. Fine aged rum. Nutmeg and ginger. Warm fruitcake.

Final Thoughts: whoa. The mad brewers are certainly not mad unless you consider a passionate love and genius for fabulous beers of fantabulous flavors. If you ever stumble across a bottle of DeDolle Oerbier, or any DeDolle beer for that matter, grab a few and count yourself blessed.

this one pours a cloudy light orange with an off white head. Aroma was lots of sweeter belgian candy sugar as well as some nice spices too. Flavor was a great blend of yeast, candy sugar, coriander and lemon zest. Good stuff.
33 cl bottle at Gråsälstasting # 2. Poured brown in colour with tan fluffy head. Quite sour in aroma. Flavour dark dried fruits with a bit of yeast also.

Bottle. Pours an unclear, dark brown with a thick creamy head. This one has a massive aroma. Pleasant, sweet fruitiness, leather and a light whiff of alcohol. Complex, heavy flavour, with a lot of lightly burned, oaky malts. Theres notes of liquorice, tar, dried fruit, and some alcohol. Malt sticks in the finish, giving it a nice staying sweetness.

Bottle @Gråsälstasting #2. Poured dark amber color with a thick white head. Aroma is malt, caramel and earthy notes. Flavor is more sweet malty, intensively spiced, hint of alcohol and yeast. Quite complex and interesting beer.

Bottle from Berts Bierhuis. Dark brown pour with a big beige head. Good aroma with mostly malts and spices. Malty taste with spices, some roasted hints, liquorice, some tart hints which lead to a smooth hoppy finish. Good aftertaste. Wonderfull balance. This is indeed a very nice beer!
2005 bottle generously shared during RBSG. Pours a cloudy light brown. Some massive barleywine characteristics. Caramel and quite phenolic. Notes of burnt plastic of coconut. A bit of a mess.

Bottle at home. Murky dark brown with reddish highlights. No head. Aroma is spicy wooden Belgian, cloves, berries and subtle whiskey alcohol. Taste is fruity & sweet/sour, with some oakiness and rich, warming alcohol notes right through. Medium bodied, rich & complex.

Sampler at CBF 2011-05-26. Hazy orange-golden with a three fingers thick, rocky head. Wooden, Belgian yeast spicy nose. Sweet flavored, honeyish and with an acidity that works well, spices and tobacco present. Fulll bodied. Syrupy and alco warm leaving a dry mouth.

330 ml bottle shared by Will at 33- thanks, Will! Pours a mostly clear amber color with a big, foamy beige head. Aroma is musty, with basement funk, dust, dry malts, and rich pit fruits. Flavor of Belgian yeast, a lot of fruits- dried dark fruits, plums, and overripe apple- along with some earthy funk and old cheese. Medium-bodied, with medium carbonation and a dry, funky mouthfeel. Interesting, complex Belgian strong ale.

Gushing. Noch zurückhaltender Antrunk, der nur wenige würzige Nuancen enthält. Als erstes wird das Bier etwas süß, dann kommen dezente Kräuternoten auf, alles aber weiterhin nicht übermäßig würzig. Die alkoholische Stärke wird eher nebenbei ersichtlich durch bittere Gewürznoten, die nicht verschwinden möchten. Zum Ende bittere, etwas säuerlich, malzig-kräuterartig. Ausgewogen, das Bier könnte aber etwas würziger sein! 12/10/8/11/11/11

Im Geruch weinartig, süßlich-malzig und auch fruchtig. Im Antrunk süß und malzig, dabei sehr forsch auftretend. Dann rosinig und ab der Mitte alkoholische Züge. Hier wird das Bier ssüßlich-fruchtig und tendiert zum Marzipanaroma. Im Abschied kommt der Alkohol dann stark durch, wirkt kratzig und schmälert das bisher gute Bild. Gleichwohl süßlich-malzig. 
Starkes Bier mit Tiefe und viel dominantem Alkohol. Ein Likör unter den Bieren.Test vom 2.2.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Smells malty and fruity (red and citrus.) Pretty dark reddish brown in color with a teal cream head.  A strong sweet flavor dominates this beer; it tastes like sugar, malt, cherry, and both red and white wine.  It fades into champagne.  The aftertaste had whiskey notes and you taste the 9% throughout and after.  Unique in its sourness compared to other Belgian strongs i have had.

On draft.  Not sure what happened.  Started out really good.  Foamy head, beautiful magenta color, and subtle dried forest fruit and caramel aromas.  Nice malt balance and clean finish with bing cherry notes...but then 3/4 through some unpleasing funk crept in mainly on the taste.  Dirty tap lines?

Appearance: Chocolate brown. Hazy. Nice tan head. Some sediments.
Aroma: Lots of malt. Some tart fruit. Tar?
Taste: Malt and some slightly tart fruit. Some alcohol. Nice.
Info: 330ml bottle, 12/5-2011, 41/500

0.33l bottle. Pours a completely cloudy brown-murky body with a big lasting fluffy off-white head leaving good lacing. Has a little alcohol in the aroma along with dark fruits, raisin, figs and a near spicy and herbal touch. Lively carbonated, medium bodied and has a oily and slightly sticky texture. Really nice and complex brew this. You can sense the alcohol with a mild stingy aftertaste, more raisins, some woody cherries and lots of nice dark fruity flavors with plums and figs. A perfect combo with some good sharp cheese.

33 cl. bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Very hazy dark brown colour with red hues. Very large head, that settles very slowly to a thick cap. Aromas: A lot of Belgian yeast here!  Big amounts of dark fruits like plums and dates. The malts are very present, with caramel and toffee. Dark fruits are also present in taste, combined with notes of anis.Light sweetness, little/flat carbonation, full body, long lasting finish, with a nice warming feeling from the alcohol. A very complex beer, that deserves a high rating!
Slighty tart, reminds me of a less refined abt12, dark fruits kinda simple

Very morish and well executed beer. The sort of beer youd be happy to drink everyday. Small head, between ruby and brown in colour. Aroma of sweet caramel, balancing bitterness and spice. The flavour is more bitter, with toasted notes and caramel, and a rounded fruity finish. Full body and soft palate.

Poured a deep brown color with a large light-tan head.  Aroma is very tart and fruity with lots of yeast.  Some doughy notes with cheese as well.  Taste is also pretty tart with dark fruit and brown sugar.  Finish has a really nice kick of caramel and chocolate.  Overall the body is slightly creamy and the balance is perfect between the sweet malt flavors and the tart from the yeast and the bitterness from the hops.  Great ale.

33 cl bottle, pours reddish with a nice big head, plenty of lacings and solid retention, aroma of yeast, fruit, sugar and malt, taste follows the nose but with a sligt tartness, smooth mouthfeel, super beer.

Started talking to another BAer about this and then found it the same day.

Beautiful frothy 4 finger head with an aggressive pour.
Appearance is a bit cloudy, amber, iced tea middle color.

Froth settles into nice foam.

Nose is fairly typical. Lots of Belgian yeast, candi sugar, citrus mixed with fruit and a hint of moss.

Taste is a bit maltier than expected. Lots of Earthy, yeasty bread overtones. Some phenolic banana, and hints of fig. As it oxidizes Im getting some cloying sourness.

Finish and aftertaste is a little dry, sour.

Feels syrupy and fairly high carbonation.

Not as "hot" as many fresh Belgians. Aging could mellow it a bit, but it doesnt seem carbonated enough to last more than a year or two before going full-on treacle.

Not bad. Would like to taste their version of a Quad.

330 mL bottle.  Gushes upon opening.  Pours a hazy brown to the point of opacity, with an off-white head.  Tart cherry and berry aroma.  Flavor is kind of a combination of raspberry, red cherry, and red grape, some chocolate, a little spice and molasses.  Fine palate, neither too light nor too heavy.  Its just too bad I lost some of it to the foam.

330ml bottle. This thing was a gusher. Pours a reddish brown color with huge foamy off-white head that faded quickly. The nose is  very fruity, there is a nice subtle cherry aroma, and yeasty with some carmelized sugar notes. The taste is sort of sweet. You get the fruity belgian yeast flavor and some caramel malts. I expected a slight tartness after picking up on cherries in the aroma but that is no where to be found sadly.

Bottle from Drink of Fulham. It pours cloudy mahogany, with a very thin beige head and lively carbonation. The nose is marzipan, date, fig, raisin, sweet caramel, dried pineapple, strawberry, blueberry and wood. The taste is date, raisin, fig, cherry, lemon, lime, pineapple, oak, smoke, a little astringency, leather, tobacco and cocoa. It has a really foamy mouth-feel and a very long warming finish. Its complex, very well balanced and utterly drinkable.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2013 Brown sugar and roasted malts aroma. Some hints of licorice not so much brown sugar as far as flavour goes. Apparently brewed from six different malts, wonder if it makes that much a difference.

330mL bottle, pours murky dark reddish brown with a medium white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, dried dark fruits and cotton candy. Flavour is very rich and complex, with heaps of caramel, toffee, dark fruits and a considerable amount of sweetness. Sticky, chewy palate, with a lingering finish of candied sugar. Delectable.

24 March 2011 - bottle at Brewdog Bar Edinburgh. reddish brown, almost w/ pinkish element. nose is bready alcohol and some warm cherry aromas. thin/med body and moderately fizzy. really nice. crisp and cherry malt. fun for a belgian strong ale but i expect more of a pale colour and more yeastiness.

Loverly red, black color with a thick creamy head. Aroma: dried fruits and alcohol.
Taste: medium sweet with a light sour touch. Strong alcohol taste.

Clear and glowing red brown with a huge and lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, toasted malt, dried fruit, yeasty and spicy. Flavor is rather sweet and moderate bitter. Bitter and dry finish with warming alcohol. Very complex and brilliant. 170311

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2014 §15/03/2011) [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: sweet (but not overtly so), lots of yeast and even more brown sugar-type malts, some dark fruits, bittersweet going both towards the bitter & sweet end of spectrum, somewhat not corresponding medium body, overall very nice // 1987 Vintage bottle @ Kulminator // brewed back when they were still using Rodenbach yeast & same age as me // dark brown ruby with a tanned head // smell is 100 % oxidization // taste is slightly oxidized, wood, sour malt, cherry & liqueur cherries, cobwebs, lacto, brett, sour yeast, oxidized but still in quit good & virtually no beer if any all is going to be in top shape this old but this is not bad, obviously over the hill wonder how this tasted like when it was let us say about 4 years old // sour malt body, some carb. still left, not much /////// Very solid beer, should rate this again properly & rate higher /// This is way better than 3.9

UPDATED: APR 11, 2015 Bottle 330ml @ yngwie
Pours dark reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, yeast alcohol, and some spices. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long warm, caramel yeasty and light sour finish. Body is medium to full, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle 330ml @ home
[Trade by Dedollewaitor] Pours reddish brown with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of sweet dried fruits, caramel and alcohol. Taste is light sweet and light sour bitter with a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is fizzy [6 3 4 3 10 = 2.6 3/8/2011]

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a slightly see through hazy, dark brown with a big tan head that takes forever to settle down. Aroma is dark fruits, wood and alcohol. Specifically plums and figs on the nose. Raisins are prominant on the palate. Wine has been mentioned but it almost has the flavour of a port. Complex dark and sour fruits on the palate as well
At ZBF 2011, Sint-Niklaas: Hazy brown classic brew quite sweet qith hints of caramel, and its got some wine-like character.
No mha acabat de convèncer, se li notava molta el gas, tenia un gust com de vi, curiós.

Poured into a trappist from a bottle. Beautiful hazy amber/brown with a magnificent head. Aroma is fruity, with a touch of something I know, but cant quite place. Tart, fruity and exotic. A sour, yet warm after taste lingers. What a great beer.
Dark Amber with a full head and thick lacing.  Taste is of whiskey and caramel, slightly sour.  Heavy to drink, but one at a time is excellent.

Bottle courtesy BelgianBeerGal. Pours a murky brown color with a tannish head. Aroma is woody, aged and slightly tart. Sour raisins on the nose. Flavor is tart fruit, sharp yeast and aged notes. Big alcohol burn towards the end. Sharp.
Bottle from Cavie.  Murky brown pour with a white head.  Aroma is spice, yeast, and dark fruit.  Taste is sour fruit, tart, dry spice, and a little alcohol.
This one is a cloudy brown tootsie roll color. It smells fruity and the taste is similar. The after taste is a little bitter and lingers on the back of the tongue. The texture is watery and thin.
Bottle thanks to Cavie. THICK white head. Pours dark. Smells like sour fruit. Tastes like sour fruit.

On tap at Issac Newtons. A brilliant hazel pour with a dark sweet fruit and bread aroma. Yeasty, raisin taste with an alcohol and mild hop bite.

A really amazing brew.

On tap at the local option. Ill admit, im biased. This brew really hits a place that I seem to have an affinity with. I just love the dark fruits, dark cherries in the Belgian strong style. This one isnt quite as complex as the pannepot, but that is quite alright. Dark fruits, Belgian sugars, a slight spicy feel, and this sort of slight earthy feel as well. Really nice

On tap at Blind Tiger Ale house one thursday afternoon.  Pours a dark brownish orange with nice head.  taste is nutty, caramel, dark fruits, slighty tart and crisp on finish maybe a hint of cocoa as well.  really enjoyable.

Dark brown beer with big and blond beige head. Aroma is full of dark fruits, some roastiness, sourness, lemon and spicyness. Nicely full bodied and smooth to drink. Taste is slightly roasted, sourness, dark fruitness and strong spicyness; complex, hardly described, biting sour taste. Interesting beer, where sourness meets dark fruits and spicyness, but thats not totally convinced me.

Picked up this bottle a few weeks ago. Pours a ruby brown with an off whyd head and some crazy lacing. Head refuses to die down. Nose brings cherries, caramel, dark fruits, and slice. Taste really ramps up a dark cherry slash currant flavor with some dark drugs as well. A bit of spice as well. Feel is nice win prickly carbonation and some booze. Drinks quite well. Really tasty.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-07-2010
Pours hazy brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, cherries, wine, Belgian yeast.  Sweet and fruity - with a sour and slightly tart finish.  Nice brew.

330 ml bottle. Deep reddish brown colour. Medium-sized off-white head. High carbonation level, and the texture is very fizzy. Rich and spicy aroma with notes of black pepper and cinnamon. Funky, but mostly sweet in the nose. Carbonation dominates the mouthfeel. Rich flavours. Sugars clearly used to make this beer.  A little cloying perhaps, but overall an enjoyable beer.

33cl. 051/502781.  Into my GI chalice produced about 3 inches of head had to let it settle a bit to empty the bottle.  A cloudy caramel color.  Aroma o f caramel and a hint of cherry.  A very smooth and creamy palate with just he right amt of carbonation.  Tastes of roasty caramel, raisins, and a mild tartness.  Finishes with a hint of coffee.   A very unique brew.
330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy ruby brown with a medium head.  Aroma is yeast, dark fruity malt and some alcohol.  Sharp raisin to start.  Red wine and some tart notes in the finish.

Pours hazy light mahogany with a rich brown fluffy head leaving lacing. Aroma is sweet malty, fruity, cherries and red wine. Fresh fruity mouthfeel. Sweet acidy, wine like, alcohol, glue and hoppy flavor. Fruity hoppy palate. Finishes fruity sourish turning later to a great tart aftertaste.

Pours a dark brown with a thick tan foamy head. Aroma of caramel. Taste is nutty, roasted. Well Carbonated. There is something that I cant put my finger on. Maybe the blends of malt. an intresting B.S.A.

11.6oz bottle.  Murky brown pour with a big frothy light tan head.  Lovely funky aroma - sweet malts, yeast, cola, burnt sugars, and fruit grapes.  Tastes are dried fruits, nuts, port wine, grape, cherry, raisins and cocoa.  Dry yeasty palate.  Tart crisp spicy finish.  Complex and difficult to describe.  Like some of their others better, but still a very interesting sipper.
Bottle. Dark brown/orange with big tan head. Flvour is malt, caramel, dark fruit, yeast, spices, sweet and bitter.

Draft. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma is licorice, ginger, cinnamon, cherries. Taste is lightly sour, lightly hoppy, slightly boozy, and a little sweet. They nailed all of them, hah. Light mouthfeel.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2011 25/01/2011 - 33cl bottle @  home (2011-38) 
Dark ruby purple to brown beer, beige head, unstable, little adhesive. Aroma: pears, chocolate, cherries, dried fruits, liquorice. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body, creamy to oily texture. Taste: fuirty, cherries, chocolate, caramel, toffee. Aftertaste: caramel, spices, mocha even coffee. Warming alcohol in the throat. Lovely beer!

09 bottle. Pours a deep hazy brown with a creamy light tan head. Aroma has tons of dark fruits, cocoa, caramel, toffee, roasted sweet nuts, brown sugar, and sweet toast. along with some delicious wood and earthiness. Flavor starts with sweet rich plum and a touch of spice, overripe dark fruits, brown sugar, a bit cakey with chocolate and a touch tart in the creamy finish. Creamy smooth medium to medium full body and a soft carbonation. Awesome stuff, complex and smooth

On tap. Color is red brown with a white head. Aroma has some sweetness and sourishness. Same characteristics in the taste and aftertaste is lightly bitter. I expected a little bit more of this. Maybe next time I should try the bottled one so that it is a little warmer.
27th March 2008  Dark tangy beer. Quite creamy, strong tone of bitter coca cola. Fruity undertone.

Bottle @ home.  Pours a huge red/tan head with a dark maroon body.  Sour, candy sugar, Belgian-style aroma.  Flavor is a bit tart, dark Belgian ale flavor with some red fruits and brown sugar.  Quite sweet and a little bit sour flavor that is very complex and interesting.  Sweet candy sugar and a bit sour finish.  Impressive beer.

Bottle. Dark copper brown, huge fluffy light tan head that lasts quite a while. Yeasty and some earthy hoppiness on along with the dark fruit sweetness of the aroma.  Bittersweet flavors, and not as sugary as others in the style.  Drier, but very warming.  Lots of nice maltiness and dark fruits, and finishes lightly bitter.  Great balance, and really nice brew.

Pours a deep chestnut color with a massive foamy light brown head. Nose is licorice, soy sauce, artificial chocolate flavored taffy. Taste is pretty much the same. Slightly tart and a medium weight mouthfeel. Not a huge fan.

Clear brown color with reddish hues. Thick, creamy head. Aroma has whiffs of raisins, vanilla, and a strong alcohol character. The taste starts out sweet and finishes with a nice chocolate/coffee flavor. Medium bodied, smooth finish, lasting malty flavor. Highly recommended.

33 cL bottle imported.  A real gusher.  Attractive dark red beer.  Smells a little bit krieky.  Even tastes slightly kriek otherwise very much a Belgian red ale, full of flavour.  This is a stong and tasty beer, better than Id expected.

Bottle. Dark brown, average almost fully diminishing light brown head. Moderate malty aroma, sour but same time there is some sugary sweetness with fruitiness. Malty body is average, sweetish and spicy (pepper?) and some alcohol. Finish is average, malty and dryish with quite heavy alcohol and spiciness. Body is not so hefty, so this amount of alcohol and spiciness just no not work.

bottle poured a ruby brown in color with a thick one finger off white head that coated the glass and retained a covering through the whole glass. aroma has brown sugar, caramel, dark fruit, light spices, and some tobacco. mouth feel is medium with sugar coating and high side carbonation. flavor brings out belgian yeast, dark fruits, peppery spice, anise, licorice, brown sugar, and a bit of heat going into the finish. sweet but not overly so and the spice and yeast work it out well giving nice character that does not dominate allowing the beer as a whole to shine.

330cl bottle. finally getting around to rating this... pours a dark cinammon/toffee brown with a rather large fluffy light beige head.... belgiany yeast mostly favored in the aroma with a little spicy mustiness to fall alongside mildly tart dark fruits... flavors begin on the sweeter side with a belgiany yeast profile, malty in nature but then quickly making the transition to more of a tart fruitiness as well as a faint bitterness in the finish.  carbonation is lively and effervescent as it is with most de dolle brews so non-surprising to say the least (especially given the way it poured).  goes down nicely although i sensed a bit of heat as i worked my way through the glass.
Mörka bär, syrlig, lite källarsmak (och doft) Stor smak av röda bär och plommon. Vinös och en mycket fyllig och trevlig öl.

Belgian Strong Ale? Thats a broad category... more like Belgian red or even sour ale. Smell is vinous, plums, booze, smoke, a bit of caramel, slight vanilla. Taste is sweet and sour, not great. I expected more from this.

Appearance:  muddy medium brown, with lots of bubbles, a short-lived tan head, and some minor lacing.  Aroma:  like an abbey dubbel:  lots of brown sugar, caramel, and malts; a bunch of dark fruit:  raisin, cherry, plum; hint of a leathery sauna.  Taste:  very tart, hints of unripe fruit, a bit of sweet brown sugar, and a good dosing of yeast.  Finish:  lingering dry tartness and alcohol.  Notes:  I thought it was fine, but maybe I should have let it age a couple years.  Lots of carbonation kept it from getting too heavy, but the alcohol burn was pronounced.
UPDATED: SEP 21, 2011 è spessa come supergiovane, e ne va bevuta poca poca, secondo me.. però da enormi soddisfazioni, specie con un bel dolce. Grande De Dolle

Bottle/11.6oz - Pours a slightly hazy reddish brown in color with a small off-white head that stuck around to produce some minor lacing on the glass.  A bit over carbonated.  Aroma is strong of dark fruits, molasses, brown sugar with some tartness.  flavor is also mildly tart with plenty of dark fruit.  Some vinous characteristics too.  Alcohol is a bit too present for my liking.  Finish is slightly tart with lingering dark fruit flavors.  Good, but did not live up to its reputation...

Dark dusty plum, little woodsy.  Dark ruby brown, thick creamy pale tan head.  Chewy leather, cola nut, molasses, little sweet grape juice and hot with alcohol.  Id like to start drinking this beer with a minimum of 2 years on it.,

Bottle 33cl. A brown reddish beer with a nice and persistent head. Smell is malty, toasted and yeast like. Aroma is on malt and spices, Gingerbread, nice toasted notes, red fruits and dry grapes. An intense and complex body, near to quadruple style beer. Long aftertaste, on dry fruits and brown malt. Nice beer, the alcohol is very well hidden.

33cl bottle.   Dark brown with an everlasting head.   Dried fruit, cherry , strawberry, caramel, and some fruity alcohol in the aroma.   Dry and somewhat boozy with a hint of chocolate and some fried fruit.   Mildly funky and acidic as well.   Gets bitter through the finish, but hop character is low.   Medium body and high carbonation.   Almost seems a touch oxidized but thats mild.  A bit too apparent with the alcohol.
Very dark, with enormous head. Sweet and rich aroma. Flavor is similar to, and basically just as good as, a Rochefort 10.  Yes!

Had this at Max and Jesss housewarming.  Bottle from 82.  Pours a ruby brown, clear, very thin white head.  Super funky, nutty and a bit of acetone.  Quite sweet, light balsamic old oxidized caramel.  Long sweet finish.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2014 It has a very good looking Brown/red color. Aroma of pines, grapefruit, lime and yeast. Taste is also grapefruity with citrus, malty notes, lime and some very nice yeast. This sure is original (:

330 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Malja. Rated @ 1.6.2010.
Pours a dark brown colour with a light brown head. Yeast particles on the glass. Aroma of sweet malts, yeast and fruits. Flavour of caramel, dark fruits, syrup and different kinds of spices. Very pleasant flavour. Full bodied with decent carbonation. Great brew.

Bottle (33cl) from Vinmonopolet (Vika), Oslo. Clear, deep ruby colour. Massive offwhite head with unevenly sized bubbles, slowly reducing to a thick, stable layer. Very fruity and sweet aroma. Plum, raspberry, cherry, raisin, malt and caramel. The sweetness is matched by just the right acidity, giving a refreshing result. Full bodied, suitably fizzy carbonation. Lovely dessert beer.

Massive off-white head on a dark red/brown beer.  Aroma is pleasant spices (clove, nutmeg?), belgian yeast, raisin/date, and a touch of tart tang underneath.  Flavor is rich with a soft feel.  More spice, raisin/date, and a marked alcohol tinge in the finish.  Slightest tart flavor near the finish but not nearly as strong as perceived in the aroma.  One of the better belgium strong ales Ive had.

A: The pour is a dark amber color with a slight haze and a massive tan head.

S: Initially there are some tart fruit aromas followed swiftly by a blend of spices and sweet malts. Lots of caramel, candi sugar, and dark stone fruits.

T: Lots and lots of sweet dark fruit flavors immediately hit the palate--plums, raisins, and figs, to be more detailed. Some mild nutmeg flavor along with a sugary sweetness. Quite a bit of alcohol comes through as well.

M: The body is excellent and the carbonation is that wonderful intensely effervescent kind that has a light creaminess.

D: Great nose on this beer but the alcohol presence knocks down the enjoyment of this one. Might be better with some age.

When i first had this beer in belgium it blew my mind. 
Ruby Brown-Dark Brown in color. carmel head. sweet, smokey,  luscious.
unique.

I also had a bottle that i let sit too long (3 years, ouch) and it clearly had turned mediciny, syrupy more like a port (and may have mixed well with a port or certain other dessert wines)

11.2 oz bottle (bottled Jan 2010). Hazy copper/brown with a thick beige head that quickly fades to a thin layer. Aroma of caramel, dates, raisins, earthy yeast and some light alcohol. The flavor is tart, musty yeast up front then the sweet caramel malt and sugar fades in, alcohol is well hidden. Medium body with a carbonation that explodes in the mouth and becomes almost sparkling. Solid beer, well balanced and drinkable.
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Consumed with Jeff in Phoenix. A good mixture of caramel, sugar and yeast - strong spices on the front, less on the back. A good beer. At

Bottle.

Pours red-brownish with white head. Nice aroma of dark berries, spices, malt and caramel. The taste was enjoyable, a bit sour, cherries, raisins, "wood", and "milk". A very good and interesting beer.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 Very dark brown with small tan head. Caramel malts, banana, cake. Taste is very rich, sweet and sticky. Lots of alcohol compensates well and so does the sweetness, with apple. Impressive beer, a little too sweet for me. (Bottle 33 cl, 2,50 EUR & on tap at De Dolle)
Brown coloured beer with larger off-white head and lots of carbonation. Hoppy malty and sweet aroma with touches of fruit. Full sparkling palate. Finish is malty ending bitter roasted and dry.

Bottle, from 1982, at Beerwarming Party. Pours a light, ruby-brown with a bare, filmy white head. Aroma of dark cherry and funk. Flavor is sweet with caramel and toffee, along with tart currant and other dark fruits. Medium bodied with faint carbonation. Finishes with some good sweetness and funk, along with perceptible metallic hints. Very good given the age.

If you enjoy carbonation, this beer is for you.  It smelled of cherry, grape and leather and tasted of cherry and fig.  It may be kind of base, but I also felt like I was drinking a fruit punch with 7up.  The first sip was too cold and the carbonation muted many of the intricacies, but as it warmed and the carbonation dissipated I started to enjoy the beer.

Bottle from de Dolle .Dark brown colour, big head that quickly disappears. Aroma is sweet and fruity with some sour notes to it. Taste is candy sugar, very roasted and sweet with the bitterness taking over in the end. Very carbonated as always and pleasant alcohol burn. The funky sourness makes this an excellent brew.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2016 If you get a chance to visit De Dolle please do so. The folks who run it are very nice and this is on tap there which is excellent.  I love the hint of tartness from the Rodenbach yeast and it is tempered by the sweetness.  Most Yummy. Sometimes a bit too carbonated for my tastes is only downside.  Serving: Bottle and Tap

Bottle. Poured into a tulip glass a hazy opaque reddish brown color with a big tan head of tiny bubbles. The aromas I get are of apples, spice, and alocohol, some wine type notes as well. The first thing I notice when drinking this beer is the carbonation. It hits your mouth and gives a little tart flavor followed by some bitterness and maltiness. Aftertaste is slightly bitter with alcohol. Light/Medium mouthfeel. A bit pricey at $6.29/bottle but glad I tried it.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Valkendorfsgate, Bergen. Pours a deep ruby body with a solid, creamy off-white top. Nose is cherries, yeasty tartiness, wood and some earthy tones. Taste is candy sugar, toffee, booze and yeasty dried berries and fruits; cherry, raisins, red grapes. Intense flavor and a lively palate makes a balanced drinkability for this complex brew. A world class Belgian-style craft beer from De Dolle here, highly recommended.

Aroma of toffee, confectionery sugar, currant and chocolate. Appearance is ruddy, unfiltered dark brown with big tan head. Flavor matches the nose, with a little boozy apple adding some fruity sweetness. Palate is bubbly and effervescent. OMG.
Pours red with white head, aroma is odd with some sweet and tart notes. Taste is malt driven with some caramel, goes into some tart citrus and finishes sweet. Unlike any other.

POurs strongly out of the bottle, gusher. Lots of foam. Brown coloured, a small head remains in the glass. Aroma has malt, caramel, candy, coffee. Taste is complex, fullbodied, some bitterness, nuts and lots of mocca. Somewhat sweety. Nice one.

Bottle. Brown colour with large creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel and yeast. Nice sweet and spicy flavor.
Creamy palate

bottle from tops with no marked date consumed 4/27/2010.

hazy rich orange-red hued brown with a horrifically huge and rocky khaki colored head.

the smell reminds me of airy raisin brioche....mmmm... yeasty dough, brown sugar, florals, bubblegum, a little dustiness and some alcohol stinging as well. 

the flavor is very vinous and very wine-like tart on the finish. qualities before that are yeasty dough, brown sugar/candi, cinnamon, chocolate, plums and a pleasant savory note in the back. along the tartness  there is a clean dry alcohol finish. 

medium bodied and soft with ample carbonation. 8/4/8/4/16/4.0

Pours a murky brown color with a large, long lasting off-white head.  Aroma is bready and spicy, dark fruit with some tartness as well.  Flavor is caramel, spice, and dark fruit.  Sweet caramel lingers into the finish.

11.2 ounce bottle from Wine & Beer Westpark in Richmond, VA. Pours a dark murky rust brown color with a medium tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel, toffee, butterscotch and a bready, slightly vegetal note. The taste is tart cherries, vegetal notes, brown sugary malts, some spice, faint chocolate and a yeasty finish. Medium bodied, highly carbonated and smooth. Pretty good beer. 5/19/10

Appear.  Center-poured into a tulip glass. Holy head. We will be waiting to pour more. Waiting... Head is huge! (twss) Beer is a cloudy light brown/honey brown, Killer retention. Head is full of fat bulbs (expected tight finer carbonation)

Aroma. Light wheat toast notes with hints of dark fruits, faint though, falls on the back of nose. Thinkn I smell champagne yeast.

Taste. Good. This is a good beer. The alcohol is big but crucial in cutting the apparent sweetness. Well balanced flavor profile. Bread/toast qualities emerge with notes of sweetness. Hops tingle only the edges of the palate. Champagne yeast becomes more apparent, giving a big beer a much softer delivery.

Palate. Complex, Intriguing. Yeast definitly compliments style. Lighter and crisper than expected.

Overall. Very drinkable, Probably too drinkable at 9% abv. A new fav! Thanks Mike!
Bottle.  Redish brown pour with a beige head.  Spice, caramel, sour bread, brandy.  Bitter and sour finish.  Not too impressed.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2017 [6/10] Bottle that is almost a gusher, 11C. Reddish amber with a lasting thick beige head (in a Westmalle chalice). Aroma of sweet plums, yeast with a little chocolate (!?) and wood. The aroma suggests sweetness, but the taste has sourness and bitterness too. Theres a milk sourness element in the luscious mouthfeel too. Has both fortified wine and cider aspects. Complex fruit/ malt/ yeast taste thats too nice to bother picking things out. Much more interesting than the aroma suggested. An absolute cracker. [7 5 9 5 17 4.3] 
[2/11] Deep reddish amber with a cm of beige head. Aroma has dark sugars, ripe and under-ripe plums, chocolate, earth. Mouthfeel is creamy and quite carbonated - a little much perhaps. Very fruity with lots of sweet and sour plums. Alcohol is quite prominent and a little PX sherry-like. Spicy bitterness and aged vinegar sourness at the end. Lovely beer.
You need a litre glass to reliably hold a 330ml bottle. Somehow just short of earthy. Amazing balance of fruity, rich, tart, bitter, acid, vinous. Insanely great beer.
330 ml bottle a red brown colored beer with a beige head aroma spices caramel bitterness and some sourness taste fruit spices caramel bitterness some sourness  and a spicy bitter finish

Bottle, 33 cl. Good appearance, nice hazelnut color with a lightly tanned head. Aroma reveals a lot of belgian yeast doing its job with a fruitiness with some berries, a great deal of yeast sweetness along with hints of oily nuts and caramel. The taste is also very yeasty, but not as sweet as the aroma hints. The yeast contributes with some dark fruits, nuts, caramel-malts, small hoppiness in the finish. A good interpretation on the belgian strong ale.

Birra dal colore marrone scuro con schiuma cremosa.Malti tostati con una nota di caramello.Oltre che dal tostato laroma è dato da nocciole leggermente speziate,uvetta zenzero e zucchero caramellato.In risalto soprattutto il contrasto tra laroma caramellato e il sapore di frutta.Il gusto è dolce acido.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums & prunes), raisons, some caramel, and spice; Palate is slightly tart; Nicely balanced and complex; Very tasty brew - I enjoyed it.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2010 head: small 
colour: deep brown/red 
smell: dairy , malts, bubblegum 
taste: sweet, bit sour, alcohol , bit porto like , sticky texture , dry finish


vintage 2003 , when rodenbach yeast was used in the beer ! 
head: tiny 
colour: deep brown 
smell: vintage , marsepain , spices, anis , caramel , sourness, red berrys 
taste: alcohol, caramel , some mintyness , spices, heavy powerfull and alcoholic body !! , need to be carefuly sipped , not drunk  !! , candy sirup , very very stronn beer !!!
aroma: 8/10 
appearance: 2/5 
taste: 9/10 
palate: 2/5 
overall: 17/20

Pours a dark brown red color with a nice beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, hops, apples, caramels and spices.  Flavors of roasted malts, caramels, apples, wallnuts, liquorice, candy and spices.  Good carbonation, good ballance between sweet, bitter and sour, with a dry finish. Powerfull and complex with lots of flavors and well balanced. Very enjoyable.

Bottle. Reddish brown with a massive beige creamy head with soapy bubbles. Aroma is hilarious, green apples, sour candy, sugar, some caramel, caramelized fruits. Very fresh. The flavour doesnt quite match, caramel, candi sugar, dark fruits, yeast, alcohol with a frisky sourness. Some alcohol burn. The finish is a tad liquorice-like. Not in flavour, but in the peppery feel on the tongue. As usual with belgian beers, this is a bit heavily carbed. I would have liked it smoother and more mellowly carbed. Medium bodied. All in all, a different, cool brew that caught me by surprise.

330 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 9%. The glass fills completely by a huge beige head, and the brown beer appears only slowly. Intense fruity aroma with berry notes, also some oaky, spicy and vinous notes. The flavour has a powerful malty sweetness and intense vinous notes, warming mouthfeel. Notes of oak and berries again. Awesome beer.
Bottle split with Dallas, Andrew, and Tony. Plums and dark fruit, yeast, and Belgian spice.

33cl bottle at Håndverkerstuene. No batch or date info. Dark orange/golden colour with a medium big head. Aroma is fruity with notes of yeast and oak. Some red berries as well. Flavour is bitter and a tad carbonated. Oak and lingonberries. Some yeast and honey as well. A decent beer, but not my favorite from De Dolle.
Bottle at Zotte, Amsterdam. Red-brown with a small off-white head. Dried fruits, raisins soaked in liquor, cognac and chocolate in the aroma. Medium sweetness on a medium body.
Bottle.  Plums and dark fruit,  yeast, and Belgian spice.  A solid Belgian ale
Had with the guys. Pour is medium dark copper. Aroma is alcohol and sweet malts. Flavor is smooth with hints of vanilla and banana.

Dark brown almost black pour, huge and thick brown head.
Aroma of hoppy yeasty fruit, a bit sweaty at the start.
Flavour is strong hoppy bitterness, yet very smooth, sweet fruits, smokey bitter liquorice. Long lingering flavours. Awesome beer, only the aroma brings the score down a bit.

330ml bottle at a pub in Brugge, Belgium. Pours dark brown- red. Begie head. Aroma and flavor is sweet from burnt sugar and cola. Flavor is also peppery and it has a big bubbly palate. It´s complex and brings a lot when trying it.

Bottle.

A - Deep hazy chestnut brown with a slight orange hue. A bit larger than average, bubbly, light beige head. Average retention with a good sticky layer of lacing left.

S - Fairly vinous taste with a lot of raisin and some grape along with some other dark fruit. A touch of licorice and a little tartness. Fairly well spiced with a hint of alcohol present.

T - Initial taste has a good amount of malt, which quickly gives way to a spiced raisin flavor (along with some other dark fruit). Mid sip has a lot of dark fruit and spices, some yeast and candi sugar, a hint of warming alcohol, and just a bit of earthy and hoppy flavors. Finishes with the dark fruit (particularly raisin) and spice.

M - Medium, starting to make progress toward full, body. A bit above average carbonation. Fairly smooth, but is a bit tingly and warming on the finish.

D - Good drinkability. The flavors are well balanced, and taste good with enough complexity to keep it interesting. The slightly tart and vinous aspect is nice and makes me want to sip on some more.

Notes: Nice BSDA that has a bit more tart and vinous flavors than other similar beers. Very well spiced, put the vinous/tart flavors cut that a bit. Full of raisin and grape like flavors. Good, solid beer to drink from a good brewery. Nice for a slightly different beer if you want a BSDA. Definitely worth a try.

330mL into Oerbier glass. Pours a muddy brown with a thin, yellowish head. Not a gusher! Not much retention and little smidgens of yellow lace. Aroma is maple, licorice, funk, scotch ale malts. Taste is sweet, rich, boozy, earthy, full of overripe dark fruits (prunes, raisins), plus a little medicinal/odd character. Pretty yummy overall. Alcohol balances the intense sweetness. Has a rich body, no cloying. I can see how this is a good base beer for the sour version, one of my favorite beers of all time.

33 cl bottle. Pours amber / brown colour with a dense tan head. Malty, yeasty aroma with some fruity sweetness and hints of alcohol. Yeasty flavor. Some dark fruit sweetness and a bit of alcohol in the finish.

33cl bottle. Pours a hazy brown color with a big off-white head. Medium lasting and good lacing foam. Aroma is similar to Arabier to me, but more malty: malty sweetness, alcoholic warm and some hoppy floral notes. Dried fruits and prunes in my nose too. Taste is very warm: malty sweetness and alcohol again. Here alcohol is less hidden than in Arabier and the 1° more is perceivable. Full bodied beer with high carbonation (it needs more than a spin in the glass to reduce it to a pleasantly drinkable level). Overall, a good beer, lacking a bit of complexity in the taste.

Bottle pour to Oerbier glass (yes I am a nerd) gives cloudy medium brown with very thick persistent tan head.  Great aroma of grapes and dark fruits.  Taste a bit tart but interesting with dark fruits, yeast, malts. spices.  Not much in the way of hops, but a little bitterness lingers.  Mouth feel fairly thick and smooth.  Alcohol not too evident but there is a bit of a burn on the finish.

This is a really good beer.

Bottle at home. Pours a hazy dark ruby red with a very thick foamy off-white head. Aroma of strong licorice, dark malts, clove and other spices. Flavor is intensely licorice, mint, caramel and spices with bitterness and some sweetness. Slightly warming in the finish. Nice brew.
Pours a cloudy brown with a two finger tan head.  Aroma is a little sour funk, candy sugar, apple and malt. Flavor is roasted malt, sugar, prunes, and a nice tart kick.

Pours dark red/brown with a huge bellowing off-white head that fades into a fingers width. Aroma is of figs, plums, grapes, a little citrus, and alcohol. Taste is slightly strong on the alcohol at first but quickly fades into a nice sweet/fruity ending, a little bit of floral hops at the end as well.
Why isnt cantalope melon named in the list here? Some citrus, metal. Nice head. First sip knocks you down. Candy followed by hoppyness. Great beer.

Bottle, home.  De Dolle is an excellent brewery and this is another excellent De Dolle beer.  Oerbier pours a bright, brilliant shade of ruby with an enormous, foamy head.  The head is fantastic.  The beer has a sweet caramel malt fruitiness aroma.  There are grapes, apricots, and cherries on top of caramel and earth.  It has a sweet and sour bite in the flavor.  Theres a very mild soy sauce flavor in the finish, but it doesnt detract.  Mouthfeel is very lively, which, while a fun change, makes drinking almost difficult.  This beer picks up with some time in the glass, so sip it slowly and enjoy.

(.33cl bottle)  Pours a chocolate color with thick tan head.  The carbonation is huge.  I did pour the sediment rather than leaving the sediment in a separate glass.  Incredible aroma of yeast and bread.  Nice caramel flavor with chocolate tones and ripe bananas.  Slight sourness at the end.  Very complex beer that leaves you licking your lips.  This is a great beer!

Having drank this delicious brew over so many occasions, I am going to do my best to simply put that this brew, whether fresh, a year to five+ years old (aged properly), will always continue to burst with flavor to me.  De Dolle does something special, and I will continue to open these guys from time to time, continually impressed by their attention to detail and preservation of the true depth of bier in general.  Love it!!

Thanks to tampabrew for pulling this one out.

A: Pours a deeper shade of brown with hints of red. Nice tan head that does provide a bit of lace.

S: Notes of dark fruit, sweet apple, and yeast.

T: Lightly tart with notes of black cherry and wonderful malt sweetness. Brown sugar and caramel for sure. Notes of raisin and a touch of tobacco.

M: Medium in body, creamy finish.

The color its amber - red , spume intense color like  cream.
At aroma I can feel a lot of fruit and nuts ...
The taste its so sweet for start , but finish with a good bitter...

(bottle) pours a lightly hazy ruby colour with a frothy off-white head. nondescript aroma of cactus juice and powdered sugar. flavour is strawberries and caramel with a light herbal hoppy finish. thin alcoholic body, quite sweet with fizzy carbonation.

11.6 ounce bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar ($5.19).  Pours a deep garnet with giant fluffy off-white head that has good retention.  Aroma of musty Belgian yeast, bright sweet malts, and spice.  Taste also very malty and lightly sweet with chocolate tones, dark fruit, and spice.  Great carbonation and the alcohol is well concealed.  (852, 243)

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from Sperryville Corner Store.
It pours a dark amber color with a very effervescent tan head.  The nose is filled with brown sugar and lager like notes.  Overall the nose was very light.  The taste is fruity with notes of apricot, clove, spices, raisin, and a substantial earthy bitterness. A bit of pear and prune comes out as the beer warms.  The mouthfeel is light with a high level of carbonation and a good bit of dryness.  This is a solid brew.  Very sessionable and smooth.  Definitely worth giving a try.

on tap @ 4:20. bel colore ambra intenso, tendente al brown..bellissima schiuma nocciala chiaro, molto compatta...Al naso grande complessità di profumi di frutta matura, su tutti pera, uva e banana..al palato non molto carbonata ma corposa e molto gardevole, ben mascherati i 9 gradi alcolici, molto intensa e complessa anche al palato con una notevole nota sapida e un bello spunto amaro finale.
bott. aroma chiaramente più speziato e intenso dellara. in bocca risulta maltata speziature di liquirizia e caramello.finale legermente luppolato.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a dense off-white head. An intriguing aroma straight up with sour cherries, wood, chocolate and earthy notes. The flavour is tart cherries, chocolate, oak and alcohol. Its all blended very nicely and a pleasant warmth from the alcohol in the finish. A finely brewed beer for sure. Cheers Jonno for sharing!

33 cl. bottle.  Pours a murkey brown with giant foamy beige head.  Smells of white grapes, a wine dryness, yeast and spices, cherry, sweet honey.  Taste is tart, with sour berry flavor,  balanced by spices but with a dominating tartness on the finish.  I cant find a date on the bottle, but Im pretty sure this one is from around 2008 which would account for its wineyness.  Overall quite nice, though a cranberry feel a little too prominent, couldnt drink more than one.

Poured a murky brown with big belgian standard head (ie pillowy and lively). On the nose the vinious qualities are most notable - well balanced between the sweet and sour that this quality can unleash. In the mouth it is full bodied and heavy (would age well) with the candi sugar sweetness checked by the bitter rodenbach like qualities of the finish. A really well made beer. Maybe drunk a bit quickly, but found the complexity to be a bit muted. Straight forward and delicious!
Really Malty with an astringent taste and homebrewed yeast impact light foamy head but did not Hold.  Cloudy and the alcohol is well hidden

Bottled, with "SPECLBREW2" on the cap.  Poured hazy, medium brown with an almost instantaneous two-finger cap of dense beige head.. lovely!  The aroma picked up rich vinous notes, raisins, and brown sugar paired with white peppery and clovey impressions from the yeast.. some complementary sourness was evident along with mild alcohol warmth.  The flavor opened with tart, vinegary redder fruits, cherry dust, and vinous notes, moving on to more fruit, English toffee, and caramel at the core.. fruity sourness and spicy yeast around and through the finish.. balance was near perfect.  Medium-ish bodied with dense, rolling carbonation across the palate.. sourness was welcome and complementary, cutting through the sweetness, and helping contribute to the dry finish.  Excellent brew!

birra scura con un bellissimo cappello bianco e compatto.
gusto molto intenso,con note molto accentuate di liquirizia.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2010 Sweet, fruity aroma.  Deep red/brown-amber color with excellent tan head.  Fruity strawberry aroma.   Complex tastes sweet light fruity-cherry flavor with a spiciness that turns to a roastiness with a bit of an alcohol finish.  Excellent!

Notes:  Bottle at Brugs Beertje and also at Zythos 10

Pours attractive reddish brown with a thick beige head. Aromas of dried fruits, citrus, yeast but also wine-like and hints of oak-aged whisky.. The taste is beautifully balanced between bitter hops tones and malty sweetness, mild creamy and delicately sour. This is put together so well. Finish is long, dry and warming. A Classic.

Buyed me some bottles of this beer cause of the good ratings this one gets. The taste is very rich, but for some reason, in my mouth I have the feeling there are some flavours that arent matching really. A bit sad, cause this could be great taste.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pretty brown cloudy pour into a trappist glass that left a generous tan head.  Aroma of brown sugar, Belgian yeast, caramel and brandy.  Fantastic medium body taste of yeast, sugar, dark fruit and caramel with an even so slight dry sweet finish that hides the alcohol.  Great brew.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2016 Bottle, relatively fresh 1/24/2010
Lovely. Woody, hints of sour but not pushing into reserva territory. Chocolate, grapes, and rye, complex and interesting and so solid as a base that I wonder if it doesnt surpass the reserva. Yum! 8/4/8/4/16

Bottle 9/5/2016 Bottle following an arabier, and not really measuring up. Much darker pour, malt driven, substantially more alcoholic feel despite a 1% difference only. Agar and caramel on the nose. The brett if any is not nearly as heavy as in the arabier; not much of the sour though I suppose I can see how people notice it, sweeter than the arabier. Its a nice belgian but its not genius like the other. The rating can stand.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2011 Details: 33cl bottle
Tasting notes: As always quite lively when you pour it. Black color, deepred shine and a large beige head. The aroma is a mix of sweet candy sugar and a slight tartness, after a while you smell some spices. The flavor is mainly sour with some slight sweet malty flavor. The finish is dry. Carbonisation is a bit too harsh in my opinion. Medium body that combined with the sourness gives it a very good drinkability.
Conclusion: Interesting character, good aging capabilities.

Serving date: 2009-03-18. Best before: end of August 2009. Served in tulip.

Dark brown with deep red hues. Slightly Cloudy. 5 cm head, pale brown color, uneven, airy and sparkly. Plenty of lacings.

Fruity aromas of cherries and apples up front. Wood, spices (cloves?) and a little twang from the alcohol. Very big and deep small, rather vinous.

Plenty of semi-sweet fruit flavors. (cherries, red grapefruit, currants). It goes a little tart in the middle, but it quickly develops some more rustic flavors - wood, yeast (not very distinct), rye bread, hints of nuts, earth, chocolaty notes and faint mint. The finish is dry for a second and has some light mineral flavors, fruit pits, grape skin and a slightly too prominent twang from the alcohol. Plenty of vinous flavors linger on. All in all a fantastic smell with big vinous flavors. It almost resembles red wine every now and then.

Creamy, yet semi-dry in the finish. Quite high levels of carbonation. It slides really easy over the tongue. The mouthfeel seems very well suited for the overall characteristics of the beer.

A fantastic beer with great complexity. I really like the vinous character of this one. The only thing stopping it from getting top grade in taste is the slightly too prominent taste of alcohol in the finish.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Hazy brown with a huge tan head... Fruity aroma with notes of cherry shining through... a touch astringent, a touch boozy... biting... none of the tartness i was expecting bc of the aroma... very complex, caramel malts yeast fruits, nice but the astringency on the palate initially threw me a bit...

Poured into a Duvel glass. Huge gusher, which I had prepared for given the fact that the other two De Dolle beers Ive had have been gushers. The mere yeast turbulence/pressure fluctuation from opening and pouring the beer filled not only the glass but the bottle with ever-rising foam. The beer is a deep, almost-purple brown with a ludicrous topography of beige suds that leaves lace chunks everywhere. The aroma is caramely at its base with accents of souring fruit, cocoa powder, cola, sherry, and a coppery metallic note. Flavor is sweet and spicy with a solid warming alcohol presence. Cinnamon, citrus, slight acidity, toffee, dark bread. Full-bodied with (obviously) too much carbonation, but with a little time it gains drinkability. A nice rich sipper.

Wow.  Really enjoyed this beer.  Malty and sour.  More fruity then the Arabier.  Love the sour and carbonation mix.  Hard to tell if I am tasting a hint of chocolate or caramel.  De Dolle makes great beers.

330ml Bottle at the Valley Bar, Scarborough 05/12/2009
Big fruit aroma. Amber coloured strong in alcohol and fruity with a crisp and slightly bitter full malt finish.

Hazy Hazel nut colour, thin head. Aroma is very rich with notes of candy. bread, malt and dark fruit. The flavour is also very rich and bready with a strange misplaced chocolate flavour, fruity and delicious. Really great beer. You are still tasting it minutes later and the fruity flavours just keep coming. Like I said. Great.

Bottle, brought back from my Seattle trip, shared with Cole and hobbersr. A sweet, malty, and very mildly sour brew, notes of tart berries, jujube candies, cinnamon, pepper, and a darker, earthier side as well. Palate is Rich and in the bready/cakey range, with more spics, plus both tropical and winter fruits, plus mild berries. Finish is bananas, lemons, and apples, plus marmalade and burnt toast. Very fine, Champagne-like carbonation. Rich and gorgeous, but also very drinkable. Not quite the showstopper that the Oerbier Reserva is, but a mighty fine brew!

Brown with some orange hue. Pillowy,lasting head which leaves great lacing. Aroma of sweet bread,toffee,house yeast,and light flower. Lively carbonation makes this seem a little less hefty than it is. Good flavor balance of fruity,sweet malt with underlying yeast,and earth flavors. Little damp wood as well. Lingering sweet,tart,and more of a hop presence than expected. Pretty dry. Delicate,and dangerously drinkable. Seems it was gone in just a few gulps. I love De Dolle

Shared with my Lethbridge ratebeer buddies, Cole and savvy1982. Thanks for the share Kyle! Pours a burnt orange colour with a yellow/gray head. The aroma is sweet and bretty with Belgian candy dominant. The flavor is very complex. Cherries, orange peel, cake, plum skin, bitter chocolate, lemon, and charcoal. This tastes very good. nice mouth feel. Fantastic brew!

Bottle from Utobeer Market Stall. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aromas of vanilla, dark fruits, toffee, brown sugar. Flavours of chocolate, plum pudding, raisins, licorice, slight sourness. Good sweet, hoppy mouthfeel. Finishes with warming alcohol and a gentle bitterness. Excellent stuff.

From lithy via trade.  The pour was dark brown and a bit cloudy.  The head was short and white with thin bits of lacing.  Aromas of dark fruit, yeast, malts and a whiff of booze.  The flavor is mostly yeast and fruit.  Theres a bit of warming alcohol towards the finish.  Body isnt that thick and it goes down easy.  Tasty.

330. Pours a nearly opaque dark brown with a dense, creamy, bubbly, surging tan head that roars all the way up out of the glass like a devils tower. Dense sheets of stringy lace coming down the sides of the glass. Dark molasses and burnt sugar notes on the nose, along with some tangy copper and a bit of sour apple. Vinous. Creamy medium body bursting with tight fine carbonation.Cola, molasses, slight metallic tang, wood, and big vinous bursts on the mid-palate. Lovely, lovely beer. Cant believe I never rated it before now.

A nose of chocolate, black currant, alcohol and yeast. Taste is of red wine, raspberries, cherries and dried, fermented fruit. Its acidic, and the finish is a bit dry, and has a pinch of alcohol in it. Halfway through the taste, a kick-ass complex bitterness comes out and dominates. Its not a hoppy, flowery bitterness, but rather a "green", raw, plant-like bitterness. Like chewing on the white stuff between a grapefruits pulp and peel.
This brew is surprisingly tart and sour! Strange, as it tasted more like a regular belgian strong fresh, just 6 months ago. Back then it was just average. Now its a masterpiece truly worthy of its hype. Its amazingly complex, and it sure beats all the belgian strongs, lambics and sours that has a rating below 4 here on ratebeer imo. Just dont have it fresh. Its really not the same beer. I hope that explains the low rating its gotten.
Sweet nutty malt aroma. Dark brown color with a large white head. moderate sweetness in the beginning with a alcohol bite at the end.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 33cl Bottle. Poured a murky amber with a large beige head that lasts some time. Very complex aroma and taste: raisin, sour apple, grapes, De Dolle yeast, sweet malts and booze stand out. The carbonation was very strong at first but mellowed near the end of my glass... and the flavors seemed to blend better too. Close to a medium body, great depth, complex, balanced like a de Kooning painting. Overall excellent - one of the great beers in my book, very unique/original.
Note: Recently had a bottle of this that was about a year old: carbonation had mellowed to a "medium", more sour & tart, more blended, alcohol now almost hidden... outstanding now. I have several more of these bottles to age... plan on opening one every 5 years.

Neutral looking brown with a small beige head. Aroma is vinous, malty and somewhat "milky" with refreshing fruity yeast esters. Mouthfeel is lively, maybe a tad too lively at first and the brew needs to calm down in the glass for a while. Flavour is similar to aroma with deep brown, slightly acidic malt character, unique yeast character with a semi dry finish that makes this rather strong beer dangerously drinkable.

33cl Bottle, purchased at Spiritus Fermenti - Providence, RI. Intense, rich boozy apple aroma paired with juicy caramelized malt sugars and the signature De Dolle yeasts. Absolutely delicate and perfumed. Brilliant. Pours a murky rusty red-brown, with a tall finger of browned pear flesh foam. Flavor is quick and explosive. Volatile blasts of brown bread, apple brandy and hard sauce move around the palate. The high level of carbonation brings minerals and base malt to the back of the palate. Peppery and reminiscent of booze-soaked fruit cake in the sinuses. Delicious and well-done.

Nice looking brown beer, slight hazy with red higlights. aroma is malty with a fine slight tart fruityness. taste is rich, malty, slight winelike and refreshingly sour. the balans is outstanding, a fine complex beer.

Ive been waiting for this one. Good to see it back in Colorado. Very clean refreshing smell. Lightness that defies its color. carmelly and green applely malt scent. This is a great one. Such  a clean palate with an aftermath of dark fruits leading to more clean pastures. Geez, the Belgians are Gods. Ill drink this one again and Ill get more from it.

Bottle - Pours mahogany with a huge cream-colored head. Smells of sour blueberries, raisins, red wine, sweet bready malt, and a whiff of booze. Taste is raisins, sweet malt, and a sour, bitter finish. Theres some nice warmth, but it would be nice if this settled down a bit and evened out. Its a bit too syrupy and the carbonation is jacked up a bit too much. The first De Dolle beer Ive had that was a bit disappointing.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a clear burgundy beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is sweet with notes of alcohol. The flavor is malt with caramel and yeast, very complex. The palate is sweet with some alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer.

So I opened the bottle and it gushes.  "Sheesh, $6 for a bad bottle," I think, but it turns out to taste pretty good, though I am quite annoyed at having lost some of this expensive beer.   Aromas are fruity (apples, pears candied apricots), spices (allspice, clove), and the flavor is that plus some acidic prunes.  A nice beer.
Deep brown colour with thin, lacy head. Aroma of sour cherries and other red fruits. Strong fruity flavour with a floral, herbal feel and a little piquancy too.

Bottle. Slightly hazy brown/orange pour, TONS of carbonation and an unexpected aroma of apple cider.  Flavor is initially apple, spice, sweet sugar and finishes with a little alcohol heat.  I will probably buy another one of these to age, as Im sure it will only get better with a few years on it.

Clear garnet pour with a beefy thick white head. Aroma is cognac, lots of vinous qualities, tart cherry, raisin, cranberry, booze, and brown sugar. Flavor has copious fruit notes- acidic raw cranberry, yeasty dough, warming booze, caramel, plum, and biscuit. Palate is suitably effervescent, frothy, pillowy, rich and warming. Very unique and interesting.

Cloudy, brownish ruby pour with a 1 finger bubbly head. Aroma is very vinous, with notes of cognac, biscuit, Belgian yeast, tart cherry, plum, raisin, cranberry, and a bit of brown sugar or molasses. Not an aggressive aroma, but impressively complex. Flavor has great dark fruit character, with plum, raisin, cherry- much like the aroma. Also some tarter fruitiness, particularly cranberry, is evident. Yeast, dough, and biscuit comes through once again. Palate is quite effervescent, but still smooth, and not too light. Really a delicious Belgian Strong dark- my first foray into De Dolles efforts, and I must say Im impressed.

Bottle. 11.2 oz. Pours deep, honey brown with an outrageously thick head. Aroma of cherries, grapes, apples, fig, roasted malt, hops and oats. Full body with a crazy, strong finish. no traces of alcohol. Beautiful lacing. Good Belgian strong.

Bottle, 33 cl. A light brwon, light reddish beer with a white large head, becoming a medium head towards the end. The aroma is very nice, with a specific sweet and dark fruity smell. The taste is sweet, dark fruity, with some sourness, a light caramel/coffee note and ends hoppy. A beer I really enjoyed to drink, as always with beers from "De Dolle Brouwers"!

Pours cloudy medium-brown, with a three-finger beige head, good retention, fine lacing.  Aroma of pineapple, cherry, plum, biscuit, grass, a little earthy.  Medium body, tart, crisp, and zesty.  Flavors of cherry, citrus, spice, tart apple, toast, and grass, sightly warming, and a very mild bitter finish.  Well balanced.
Pours redbrown with a large beige/orange head. Aroma is sweet caramel, fruity, and a hint of hop. Flavour is malt, sweet caramel, light spice, fruity and light alcohol. Nice.

330 ml bottle - cloudy, reddish amber with lingering white head; cherries, dates and yeasty goodness; mild spice and orange peels; mild carb, silky texture; dry, rich, mildly tank; dates, prunes and raisins; pretty killer brew with an off the carts nose; berries and sticky; great stuff

Bottld 330ml. -Brown coloured, big beige head, lively carbonation, dried fruits nose with touch of spices. Toasted malts, dried fruits and spices with notes of alcohol and chocolate. Warming alcoholic finish and pleasant long-lasting aftertaste. One of the best beers Ive tried in last few weeks.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2009 smells like dried prunes, looked like dried or melted chocolate along the rim of the bottle and on the outside (may have had bad bottle, didnt notice when i bought it). massive creamy head, very carbonated, pours a brownish tint. sour sort of taste with a strong lingering tartness on the top of my mouth. wasnt overly impressed, but i do find myself wanting more... next time/soon.
