Bouteille de 33 cl. Arômes de fruits rouges et de chocolat, rappelant un vin rouge. Robe orangée assez foncée, trouble, effervescence très active. Très sèche en bouche, leffervescence très active contribue également à créer une texture intéressante. On note des fruits rouges, du chocolat, des notes terreuses. Finale sèche où lalcool est également présente. Très bon.

Musty pear aroma, not very strong. Opaque brown pour enormous tan head, sheets of carbonation emanate from the bottom of the glass. Intense and balanced flavor of malt, must, sour cherries, cloves, and apple flavored jolly rogers. Very slight chlorophenols are detectable. Malty finish. Should work fantastically well with stuffed clams

Bottle. Pours deep, dark red, almost brown, with a lasting yellowish head. Spicy, fruity nose with a very similar flavour although toffee, clove and liquorice are all prominent. Very frothy, very tasty, very interesting.

Chestnut pour with a frothy offwhite head.  Aroma is toasted malts with some breadiness.  Flavor is more complex, with the toasted malt upfront followed by some slight yeastiness and nectar fruit.  complex and delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2012 Cloudy amber with giant light tan head.  Aroma of pumpernickel bread with raisins.  Taste of malt and licorice.  Complex and full of character. 4.1
2008 bottle on 21 December 2012, courtesy of Greg at Birreria Paradiso Georgetown - thanks!  Aroma has prunes, raisins, dates, figs. Taste has winter fruit, figs, prunes. A totally different beer.

Dark, chestnut brown pour with thick, off white head. Aroma of yeast, nut, and caramel. Intense, yeast flavor with lots of fruit and caramel. Well carbonated mouthfeel with sweet, yeasty finish. This is a pretty amazing beer.

Bottle. Rich toffee colored beer with a huge tan head. Dark fruit and grape aroma with some sweet caramel. Toffee and nut flavors with stone fruit, yeast and some chocolate. Medium-plus bodied. Chocolate and stone fruit/grapes lingers with rich malt. Some alcohol noticeable.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown colour with a huge off-white head. Malty aroam with notes of berries and grapes. The flavour is sweet malty, berries, dried fruits, spices and grapes, notes of alcohol in the finish. Very tasty brew with an interesting vinous touch.

I drank from a bottle and into a chalice.

The beer pours a dark brown with a white creamy head.  There is a decent amount of lacing.

It smells like sweet chocolate, nuts,  and malt.

It tastes sweet, hints of chocolate and wood.  Not a great beer, but ok.
Bottle. Dark brownish pour opaque side of translucent with little to no head. Aroma of fruit and nuts. Mouthfeel is different then expected. Flavor is of oak and cherry kind of weird.

bottle.  pours a mahogany with a nice big foamy tan head.  maybe a little too big.  aroma of tangy fruit, wood, dark fruits, grapes. flavor is slightly sweet, tangy, purple grapes.  alcohol is well hidden.  pretty tasty, neat, and different

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of cookie, caramel and milk chocolate, light herbs for the hops, moderate yeast note of dough, with date, brown sugar and alcohol in the background. Head is large, fizzy at first but settles down to creamy, off-whie with good lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is muddy dark brown with a few large particles. Flavor starts lightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lighly sweet and acidic and faintly bitter. Palate is medium, oily, with a fizzy carbonation and a moderately alcoholic finish. This is a nice, well rounded Belgian Strong Ale. The richness balances well with the carbonation.

375 Bottle into snifter (051/502781... whatever that means).  Well FUCK me!  This goddamned thing gushed all over my fucking couch, table, and carpet (as I rushed to the kitchen to hold it over the sink).  Ive had gushers, but this has been by far the worst.  EVERYWHERE! Probably half the bottle left, or less.  Oh wait,  I just now checked and poured the remnants into my snifter... 1/4 OF A FUCKING BOTTLE left.  Waste of my money.  I was really looking forward to this one.  I Have heard De Dolle is known for gushers (and I have had my fair share of gushers from them before), so sorry fuckers, youre getting a .5 for this one, despite whatever quality the beer may exhibit.  Send me a free bottle and I will re-rate it.  Definitely not BUYING this again (I know I am holding what some may consider a silly grudge by doing this, but 7+ dollars per 375 is absurd in itself... but to have 75% of that 375ml gush away and fuck up my couch to boot... fuck that).  Ok because of RBs fascist Low Rating Alert, 1.0 is the lowest I can give this.

blurry orange-brown, big but quickly receding light beige head.
licorice aroma, a bit artificial, and under that is malt and dark fruit with vanilla and some smoke.
flavor is more fruity and malty, with serious alcohol and dry sweet finish.
very sharp carbonation, a bit of a thin body.
Bottle. Murky brown pour with a good beige head on top. Really fruity and spicy aroma. Taste of dark fruit, caramel, very rich, sweet, spice, very Belgian. Smooth drinking, very nice indeed.

Pours a muddy reddish brown, with a giant head. Lots of (overripe) fruit esters in the aroma - apple, cherry, grape, and even some peach. Candi sugar and lemon meringue as well. This drinks like an effervescent red wine. Deeper, toastier malts come through in the flavor, along with berries and a bunch of dry hops to offset those fruits. This ones definitely on steroids - powerful flavor, and the alcohol shows... but somehow I dont mind it as much in here. Crazy brew - Im not sure Id ever want more than a glass, but its extremely complex. Good stuff!

Bottle. Pours chestnut brown coloured with a big fluffy off white head. Aromas of licorice, yeast, dried fruit and sugar. Semi tart flavour with notes of chestnuts, sweet malt, sour vinous touch and berries.

This is Chimay Rouge with a hard on. Caramel brown pour with a huge puffy tan head releases billowing aromas of yeast fruit and citrus that prickle the sense. The body has ruby hightlights. Taste lemony tartness and darkly intense dried fruits, with great dry and viney hopping to counter the substantial sweetness. Also some berry, pinot grape,and liquorice  Its perfect. It should be a Trappist and will age better than any Chimay if the structure of the body, hopping and alcohol are any indication. An exercise in purity of style. The assertive character (and aggressive bottle-conditioning) makes this no less impressive than a good bottle of Westy 12.

aroma of pit fruits, sweet alcohol and light hops. appearance is nearly opaque with ruby edges. very sturdy head. flavor is of well constructed, potent malt laced with and exuding booze. a powerful and complex brew.
Pours a caramel color with a tan head. Aroma of caramel, apple, and other fruit. Flavor is of fruit and a warm alcohol finish. A very flavorful and complex beer, I like this one.

Bottled 33cl from crackedkettle.com. It pours a hazy ruby beer with a nice creamy beige head. Cork, melon, apple, rose and cherry appearing the nose which is rather yeasty and faintly acidic. The taste is tart, yeasty, fruity (melon, cherry, blackberry and apple) with hints of oak and rose. Peppery, slightly salty. There is quite a bite to this beer. Subtle carbonation. Complex. Late bitterness. The alcohol is most noticeable on the swallow. Decent lacework. Surprisingly strong dry finish which is reminiscent of cherry, crackers and earthy hops. Very interesting and pleasant.

33cl bottle from Douceurs Belges. Pours really dark amber with huge creamy head. Lots of bubbles all around the head and great lacing. Head is very persistent. Palate is quite strong carbonation. Aroma is dark fruits, strong raisins, prunes and lactic. Taste is like aroma. Some lactic hints. Notes of alcohol but not much. Some hints of chocolate also. It took me some time to get used to the taste. Nice beer, very original. Will have to taste again.
bottle, amber colour with white stable head, malty smell, taste: hoppy, grainy, malty, alcohol, roasted malts, dried fruit. Very nice beer!

Pours with a large, creamy, kahki colored head, over a murky, amber-orange body. Aroma is slightly metallic, yeasty, with banana, rum, brown sugar, light cardamon and chocolate. Taste is strong with rum, raisins, dark and slightly tart fruits, rotten fruit, chocolate and oxidation. Lively carbonation. I didnt really like this too much, and it absolutely pales next to the Reserva.
Bel colore rosso-arancione.Ottima schiuma persistente. Laroma non è molto complesso con sentori tostati e speziati. Gusto con caramello, alcool, malto, molta dolcezza.Buono il finale.

2003 bottle @ Kulminator (listed as being the last batch to use Rodenbach yeast).  Pours muddy brown with thin, creamy whie head.  Aroma of caramel and slight oxidation.  Taste is very malty, more caramel and dark fruits.  Medium palate and finishes sweet and long.  Good stuff.

It pured a brown cloudy liquid with a small foam that left no lacing. The aroma was rich with spices and also had a hint of swamp. The flavor was rough and spicey with alot of carbon, hint of coca cola. A very interesting and good beer.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich with dark fruits, malt, yeast and caramel. Long sweet finish with distinct notes of alcohol.

Big fruity, strawberry aroma. Heavy and sweet but very highly carbonated, giving it an interesting twist. Flavor is serious strawberry with a bit of old paperback. Finishes very clean almost cleansing with a mild cherry wood flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2009 Main notes from Bottle @ home (influenced by memories from one enjoyed with wife, JoeinUccle and a friend of his @ le Poechenellekelder last month) - after bottle gushed over the counter - poured a deep red/brown, aroma really deepstone fruit, raisins, and yeast. My wife described it in Brussels as Dr Pepper in beer form" and I think thats pretty da*n close. Fizzy, matly, with some sour cherry yeast in there. Just a great beer - really unique.
pours rich amber/brown with a large tan head. aroma is fruity and malty with some spice and a little dark fruits. drinks fizzy with some soft malts, fruity, and mild sweetness.

Bottle from City Beer in SF.  Gusher alert!  This thing exploded all over my kitchen, almost ruining my phone.  Drank the 4-5 ounces that were left.  Dark brown color with a large tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, spices, and yeast.  Flavor is sweet malt, raisin, fig, spices, and mild hops on the finish.  Fairly full, smooth palate.  Good stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2010 bottle.  pours with force... huge tan head which slowly works itself down to about a quarter inch.... pour carefully with this one.  subtle yeast and raisin notes in the aroma.  medium body, highly carbonated, and very smooth over the top of the mouth.  some more lighter citrus notes on the sides of the mouth... Really nice finish - with some cherry, wine and apple lingering at the back of the palate.  very enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2016 Bottle. Poured dark red with a large head. Aroma is very fruity with a hint of other spices and hops. Flavor is heavy and fruity. Quite sweet a beer and enjoyable. Heavy carbonation. Overall a very good beer.
Bottled in Thembi in Mestreech. Color is very dark red-brown, huge head which stays, nice lacing. Aroma has hops, spices. Bitter, roasted malts and soft hops remain. Very nice!

Massive gusher! Think I lost about a quarter of it.
Thick creamy head, copper pour with quite a lot of floating yeast.
Lots of raisins on the aroma, also spicy cloves, ginger, and candi sugar. Alcohol is reasonably well hidden. Somethings not right though, almost like bi-carb soda.
Alcohol comes into play in the taste. Lost more rich raisin and spicy characteristics. Heaps of dark malts. Alas, the alcohol is a bit to dominant.
Spot on carbonation, great amount of alcoholic heat on the palate.

bottle, foam was pooring from the bottle after opening, leaving a dark reddish liquid with huge head. Very nice and refreshing beer. fruity (cherry) but not too sweet, no hint of alcohol, tasteful, quite plain but very good nonetheless.

Bottle from Delirium in Brussels.  Pours a deep hazy brown color with a very large beige head.  Aroma is toasty malts, slight spice nuts, and fruits.  Taste is sweet, tart, and smooth.  Flavorings of spice fruits, malt sweetness, and all over a complex yeasty backbone.  Very complex and enjoyable palate.  Really enjoyed savoring this one.

Bottle. This one exploded on me and shot all over the ceiling, down the walls and all over the carpet! :( What I managed to get in my glass poured a nutshell brown with a red hued off-white head. The nose (and my apartment) has a little sour/funk to it with some cranberry hints. Flavors are bready, like rum soaked cake, nice malt profile, and a slight fruitiness and bubble gum to it. Ober-carbonate in the mouth and leaves a lingering cotton mouth.

33cl bottle.
warning!!! this beer is explosive. probably the most gushing belgian i ever opened, even though i was sort of prepared i got beer all over the place (some in the glass). creates giant growing head, making it impossible to just pour it to stop the bottle spewing beer.  i ended up with 15 out of 33 cls in my glass, the rest on the desk, on my trousers, on my shirt, out the window and a little in my keyboard. this yields a 1:1 in apperance, i prefer beers that doesnt explode when opened.
aroma is caramel and raisins. good stuff.
flavor is raisins, light fruits, dark fruits, caramel, hops, well balanced and very tasty.

[1943-20090114] 330mL bottle. Plastic raisin malt aroma has a funky yeast characteristic. Hazy, dark brown body with a medium-lasting foamy light tan head. Fruity plum raisin cake flavour with brandy malt and heavy yeast. Full body. Enjoyable.
(w/ jerc)

Beautiful hazy molasses-amber body with a billowing frothy head.  Big malt complex, toasted bread with strong roasted marshmallow caramel sweetness.  Smooth creamy chocolate notes, light peppery spice and a good lingering citrus hop bitterness. Fantastic drink.

11.2oz bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours a cloudy amber color with a slight red tinge.  A big off white head, that diminished quickly and left some spotty lacing.  Nose was sweet and quite fruity.  Flavor is also fruity with some spice, and can really taste the candied sugar.  Finish was sweet and slightly boozy.

Bottle. Nice red/brown color with a big foamy head. Aroma is a bit malty and sour with some fruity and alcoholic notes. Taste is a bit soursweet with plenty of spice,candi sugar,malt and fruity notes. Strong alcoholic finish. Dont get the hype just yet.

Pours brown with a 2 1/2 finger tan fizzy head.  Aroma is bready, malty, a little sour.  Taste is spices, malty, a little sour, some cherry, sweet.  There is a sharp carbonation bite that actually works for this beer.  I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Aroma: Malty, a bit sourish, apples, berries, earth, hops. Taste: Malty, sweet but not sticky, lightly sourish, earthy, fruit, spices, dark sugar, licorice, hops. Sweet but very balanced. Also not very phenolic and that´s a good thing in my book.

Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly deminishing head. Brown-amber not very nice colour. ælight malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Strong chocolate and week fruity notes. Long nice moderate bitter finish. Oily palate. A little disapointing but it is still a good beer.

bottle thanks to nkruback.  pours a dark brown with a huge, three-finger, off-white head.  Nose is of vinous fruit.  Taste is of vinous fruit and some spices.  Mouthfeel is medium with lots of carbonation.  Very nice.

Bottle. 
Deep burgondy with a huge short lasting brown head.
Hevy aroma of yeast and perfume.
Full body and Vinous caractere, specially when cold.
(33 cl bottle) Dark-red color with a foamy head. Smells of sirup and wood, also in the flavor. Really reminds of Kasteelbier Bruin, only a little more bitter. Very nice!

Thanks to HogTownHarry.  I think this has been aged 4 years. Appearance: Cloudy brown/red with a one finger off white head. Aroma: Dark fruit, cinnamon, vanilla, leather, sugar, yeast. Flavour: Malty, sticky, toffee, lots of carbonation on the tongue, some yeast and caramel with a long toffee finish.
Poured reddish with a white head. Aroma of fruit and candy. Citrus flavors with some caramel hints. Sweet.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pours a dark brown/red color with a nice beige foamy head. Aroma is very nice: vinous with toffee, milk chocolate, yeast, dried fruits/berries, gingerbread dough, nougat, red wine (or more of mulled wine with raisins maybe). Flavour is also very vinous and a bit fruity with notes of toffee, milk chocolate, spices, gingerbread dough, nougat and raisins. Theres a certain red wine/mulled wine character to it with a nice balanced acidity/tartness, overall this is dry and not that sweet which I like. Filling, medium to fullbodied in the mouth. Carbonation was first quite lively but it calms down a bit after while which makes all the nice flavours come out and it also makes it very smooth. Overall this a fantastic, complex and interesting beer and I look forward to try it again!

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2012 [Re-rating 120724 (old rating 4,1)]. Bottle. Pours brown-red wit a huge fluffy and creamy off white head. Sour cherries, marzipan and milk chocolate notes in the aroma. Very complex taste with notes of white pepper, cream, milk chocolate, strawberries and orange cest. Berry tartness in the aftertaste. Incredibly smooth and creamy texture.

Date: 12/1/09
Beer info: Bottled in brown 330ml bottle 9.0% abv BB N/A

Sampling Notes:
Served chilled in chalice.
Bit of a gush but well saved. Pours a milk chocolate brown body with a tight 2-inch tan head that hangs around very leisurely.
Aroma has a good richness about it; dark chocolate fused with prunes, dates, figs and raisins, dark brown sugar, liquorice, vinous berries with slight woodiness, bit of yoghurty funk business but very appealing overall.
Rich bodied, excellent length, fluffy carbonation lending to an almost milk-shake-like texture. Bit of dryness aluding to the alcohol, but not much indication otherwise.
Deeply complex and rich body; figs, prunes, plenty of dried fruit upfront, sweet nutty malt, dark chocolate, brown sugar, woody spice, definately a journey beer. Finish brings out some dryness, finish very much like a dry red-wine, tannic, quite bitter, an aire of alcohol leaving me wanting to sip again to indulge to palate once again...
Definately one of best Belgian darks ive had in a long while. Kind of wish it were easier to come buy, because this certainly gives Chimay a run for its money!
The pour had a huge head with a brownish color with a red tint.Wow, Very sour our tart however you would like to phrase it. Different maybe i had a bad bottle.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy brown color with a large beige head.  The aroma is vinous, dark fruits, caramel, some spice.  The flavor is a complex mixture of yeast, caramel malt, cherries, oak, other fruit notes, spices, with a tart finish.  Medium bodied with a little zing on the palate.  This is a solid beer from start to finish.
bottle, firm foam with a muddy brown color, malty astringent aromas, flavor of rock candy, caramel and fruit, finishes nice

very very dark brown pour, and very murky. Aroma of dark sweet fruit malts, lots of dark ripe fruit, some anise, and a touch of hops. Flavor is all dark fruit, plums, and figs, some more anise, and lots of dark sweet malt. very rich beer. Lovely stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2014 Aroma of caramel malts, huge dark fruits (figs, raisins), hops. Slightly peppery. 
Very dark brown with a strong orange tint. Huge head. Caramel flavor is big time, with raisin and fig, chocolate, tart fruits as well. It is slightly burnt, with a burnt sugar finish, complex, sweet but balanced by hops, sour, alcohol. All kinds of interesting and somewhat strange flavors going on. Very highly carbonated, mouth seems numb afterwards from bubbles, alcohol, hops, sour fruit. Certainly very interesting and original. 

1987 bottle shared by Shoulderbroken. Fabulous tart nose, ume, raisins, plums, chocolate, dirty, cloudy, dark brown with an amazing head for a 27-year-old beer. Lovely flavor of chocolate, licorice, light yogurt, tart fruits. Wonderful. Aged amazingly well, silky and soft and still fully carbonated! 8/4/8/5/17
Brown in color and cloudy with a large beige head. Aroma is of caramel, molasses and chocolate. Taste is of caramel, malt and alcohol.

bottle from grape and gourmet. pours a very dark copper, with touches of dark red and a huge, very bubble light tan head. aroma is quite spicy, very reminiscent of red wine. aromas of tart raspberries and cranberries come through nicely with just a touch of hops and some candied sugar. flavor is very bright and crisp with tastes of sweet red wine, red fruits, plums, tart apple, and a touch of oak and brown sugar. palate is medium bodied with huge carbonation and a lingering, tart fruit aftertaste. overall, a damn solid belgian strong.

Bottle @ De Kelk, Bruges. Dark amber beer. The head is big, dense and creamy. It has aromas of oak aged beers. Sharpish spicines, red berried and yeast. Some floral hops too. The flavor is sourish and dry, but it has also sweeter fruitiness or berries. Very complex. The palate is almost dull boded, lingering and somewhat acidic. The finish is tart, long and delicate. Surprisingly light and fresh for a strong ale.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2009 Served on 10 degrees Celsius. This beer that remains drinkab;e up to august 2010, gave fine fumigated white foam collar. At the first sip a fruity young  bitter strikes me. It is even slightly sourish with much young bitterhops. When swallowing a mouthful to the middle of the tongue and from there to the sides, the taste is fuller. Behind in the throat I find a palette of fruity bittersweet which pleases me nevertheless much better. But this way this terrible good beeris away much faster. Do not get what is oer on this beer. It cannot be drunk very matered with the valued durability of two year which it gets advised by the brewery. The recipe seems rather fundamental, and the secret is probable hidden in the used hop types. A beautiful and powerful beer.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of tart fruit, red wine, raisins, plums, dark ripe fruits, brown sugar, candi sugar, and caramel.  Poured copper/amber/brown in color with a small, tan, head that diminished but lasted around the edges.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Medium and large-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of caramel, brown sugar, light tart fruit, yeast, dark ripe fruit, raisins, plums, dates, port, and sherry.  Medium body.  Tingly, syrupy, coating texture.  Lively carbonation.  Sweet, yeasty, dark ripe fruit finish.

Dark brown with hints of red and two fingers of tan head that settles quickly.  Big malty aroma, candi sugar, dark fruits, prunes and alcohol.  Taste is sweet maltiness, prunes, plums, raisins, and a light thinning alcohol.

Bottle...  Poured reddish/burgandy with a frothy off-white head.  Aroma of wine and a little bit of grains.  Nice carbonation on the tongue.  Had a bit of a bitterness and a lot of wine-like flavors.  Not as sweet and tart as I would expected but still good.
Poured cloudy and amber in colour, medium tan head. Smells of wine and sour fruit. Nice fizzy palate. Good stuff.

Unique and worthy of an even higher rating than its current 98.  Distinctly Belgian but a standout from its counterparts- is that black pepper and why does it taste so right?  De Dolle has a great yeast- gives a mild tartness in the beginning and sours more as it ages giving it the character of a different beer as the sweeter fruits wane (or maybe their brightness remains but the sugar is not as prevalent) and acids take over.  Both the older and the fresher are wonderfully complex and dance on the tongue.  Having trouble finding this lately and it is quite upsetting!  One of my all-time favorites.  Amazing taste adventure every time.
Pours dark amber, dark fruits, caramel, little nutty, little spice, little yeast, little chocolate.

Pours a burnt caramel color with a tight bubbled finger thick foamy cream head. The nose is rich and complex, with a Champagne like aroma, dreid fruits, caramel and toffee. The flavor is definitely on the sweeter side, with caramel and dried fruits. Surprisingly delicate on the palate for such a dark beer and at 9%. Lasting fruit flavor.

Malty, milk chocolate aroma. Dried fruits such as prunes, dates. Sweetness of caramel and brown sugar. Hints of fresh apple and apricot. Lovely nose!
Tastes of brown sugar, cinnamon, dates. Oak, earthy flavours. Surprisingly light on the palate given its complexity.
Awesome.

Brewed in Belgium......Pours a deep amber color with nice carbonation and a fizzy white head. Aroma of spices, cherries, sweet malts, earth and caramel. Taste is of fruits, cloves, spices, wood and alcohol. The mouthfeel is robust and has a kind of chewy texture that finishes on the dry side.  Wow, Another delicious example from De Dolle.
Bottle, pours dark red/brown with a thin head.  Aroma is clean but has hints of yeast and oak.  Flavor is dark malt with a plum juice ending.  Nice.

Very nice brew. Pours a deep brownish red. Lots of aroms going on...yeast, malt, earth, wood, vanilla, even some fruit. Texture is damn near perfect. Flavor is deeply complex. Lots of dark fruit and wood, with just a touch of bitterness. Smooth and way too drinkable.

330mL bottle from Regional. Pours a deep red/orange with a dark off white head. Fizzed up like a Duvel! Aroma is quite fruity, some yeast and a lot of spice are there as well. Strong flavour, initially fruity. Fades to some spice, plums, chocolate and more I cant decipher. Lets just say its a highly complex flavour  and I love it! Highly palatable for a 9% ABV beer. Finish is long, chocolaty, fruity and dry. Very nice.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a cloudy reddish brown color with a small off white head.  Aroma was very complex.  Notes of cherries, toffee, yeast, dark fruits and some caramel.  Flavor was very fruity.  Cherries and other dark fruits dominate the flavor.  The finish was very dry.  I really enjoyed this beer, compared to the Reserva.  This was a lot more balanced it seemed, and a lot less balsamic.

Very good retention head is a tan colour beer has a misty red brown colour banana port wine plum clove malt and hop aromas as well as raisins flavour strong malt and dry at first alcohol taste plum clove banana strong so is raisin nice hop taste bitter sweetness of figs and spices tangyness in there gives the beer lift finish fruity dry light bitter tangy great.

33cl bottle, BBE 05/09. Very dark ruby, smallish beige head. The insanely deep aroma is earth and yeast, berries, cherries, slight soy sauce , liquorice toffee, coffee, roasted sugary malts and leather. Many rhymes in there. Same vinous tinge in the flavor, cherry, earth, lotsa liquorice. Dry and herbal finish, with a little tannic gooseberry. Great sourness, so complex but balanced. Medium bodied, sadly a bit over carbonated palate. Freakin fabulous beer anyway.

Bottled, 330ml aged 6 years. A beer saved for Christmas afternoon. Bronze with white head. The stuff of legends, this ages into a smooth, rich alcoholic mixture, the condition is still great, the spices have amalgamated into an ember glow instead of being aflame. There is a rich Porty feel to it, warming and delicious. Perfect for after dinner relaxing mode.

Next down the De Dolle line, their Oerbier, an unassuming but secretly delicious beer.  Like the Arabier, the Oerbier swells like a defensive toad right after the bottle cap comes off, touching the whole interior of the glass with a smooth, soft, light brown espresso colored head.  So, Im forced to wait, and wait, and wait until I can get a little aroma through the 1.5 thick armor layer of bubbles.  So I skip straight to a sip.  The flavor is moderately dry, and rich with flavors of wood, red grape, peppercorns, well cooked steak, the dry red wine quality of an inexpensive merlot, and, in general, incredibly tasty.  The aftertaste is just as impressive, leaving a trembling echo in my throat, like I just had a spoonful of a fancy red wine and peppercorn steak sauce.  Im in love!  And before I realize it, the foam has agitated itself into oblivion, letting fly the aroma - a gaseous version of the dry red grape flavor.  Easily my favorite De Dolle.
Bottle at St. Albans beer fest. A glorious beer. Too intoxitated to ellaborate.
Look is brownish red hazy color with a nice caramel hair colored head.  Smell is chocolate, fruit, darker malts, and sweet.  Taste is sweet, chocolate, and dark fruits.

From a 330mL Bottle.  Mostly cloudy, dark ruddy caramel colored body with a huge head of fizzy ivory.  

Aromas of pale chocolate and banana yeast esters float from the glass along with wisps of coconut.  Slighty nutty 

malt character with notes of teething biscuit.  Awesome perfumey yeast character.  Light bodied, heavily 

carbonated mouthfeel with a crisp, dry texture.  Flavors of banana and raisins wash over the palate in an 

invigorating, cleansing scrub.  Incredibly dry, but still takes the time to develop an awesome malt melanoiding 

character, brimming with raisins, plums, and other dark fruits.  The fruitiness of the malt is complimented 

beautifully by the yeast, which brings out faint pepper, banana, and enhancing plummy fruit characters.  An 

extended finish of rummy fruits is left lingering on the palate.  Who says you have to have a sticky, syrupy mess 

to have flavor intensity?  This beer rocks.

Grande oerbier, era un bel po’ che la volevo assaggiare, e stasera l’ho versata con noncuranza nel bicchiere (dopo averne perso un po’ con la solita sborata de dolle che mi ha macchiato la scrivania: la mia è la scrivania più profumata e appiccicosa del mondo). Nonostante fossi stanco, anzi forse proprio perché ero stanco, l’ho apprezzata tantissimo nella sua complessità orchestrata (ma mai sopraffatta) dal pungente dell’alcool, è la versione migliore di molte birre che non ce l’hanno fatta a raggiungere questi livelli.

Pours muddy brown with a substantial cream coloured head. Aromas of malt and yeast dominate bringing choc-caramel and banana. Palate shows much of the same with a big hit of licorice and spice from the high abv, not unbalanced but definately shows. Some earthy hop bitterness is on the finish to add another dimension.

Bottle (in NZ), a gusher! Pours a cloudy brown with a large foamy yellowish head. A musty aroma with banana and spice. A full malty palate, plenty of spice and alcohol. Banana medicine flavour, with marmalade and some chocolate bitterness. I’m sure this would be better without the travel.

Bottle from Brother Tuckers.  Brownish pour wtih a medium head.  Aroma is nice with fruit, yeast and very malty.  the flavor didnt match the great aroma for me.  The bottle I had was somewhat bitter and not a pleasant hop bitterness, but a weird bitterness.  It made me think I had a bad bottle??

11/6/08 notes: bottle.  Pours pink-ruby, with a huge fluffy head.  Pretty serious lacing as well.  Aroma is sweet and tart simultaneously, cherries, green apple, strawberries, and candy.  Initial flavor is filled with lively sweet fruit, which is accentuated by the pearly carbonation.  Mid-palate mellows to reveal a complexity of chocolate, malt, and perhaps some nutmeg.  Oerbier finishes very long and sticky, an extended sweet note that also reveals wood, and alcohol.  Overall, this was a fun beer to drink.  It has a beautiful pour and aroma, for one.

Bottle. Pours a deep slightly ruddy brown with a fairly massive and thick tan head. Laces the glass nicely in sheets. Just gorgeous beer. The nose is fantastic big upfront plum, fruit, some caramel, yeast aromas of bubblegum, cherry. Medium-sweet fruity caramel flavor. Very vinous, with slightly tannic fruit, some brown sugar, alcohol comes out only as it finally reaches room temperature. Very quaffable, lush carbonation and slightly dry mouthfeel, a nice bit of acidity. Great beer.

Bottle, pours dark brown with a huge frothy off-white head. Aroma of caramel and fruits and some citrusy hoppy notes. The beer is well carbonated and has lots of flavor and a long lasting finish. A Really nice beer.
Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt.  Pours a hazy medium orangish amber color.  Aroma is lightly malty, hoppy, yeasty, with a touch of fruit.  Flavor is a nice mixture of malts and fruits.

12 oz bottle.  Had this after the oerbier reserva, I probably went in the wrong order.  Completely different beer from the Reserva.  Kind of hard to describe all the nuances, but there’s defintiely brown sugar,  sugars almost like rum, yeast, a slight sour kick at the end.  Doesn’t have the weird nuances of the reserva, but I suppose it’s not supposed to.  Kind of alcoholic as it warms, really a rich, warm, tasty brew.

Really enjoyed this beer...luscious dark chocolate pour with a milk chocolate head.  Raisin, cocoa, plum, vanilla, and roasted almonds hide the 9% alcohol well.  Aroma of  molasses, cherry skin, and brown sugar are inviting.  Good brew!!!

Wow, is this a great beer.  Now granted, this is my first exposure to Belgian beer, but it sure won’t be the last.  It produced massive amounts of a tan head on the pour, even with a slow pour at a 45’ angle.  Dark fruit to the nose and a rich nutty flavor that completly hides the 9% alcohol.   This beer tasted great right from the refrigerator and as it warmed to cellar temperature.  The alcohol warmth only came it as it neared room temperature.   It did not strike me as all that tart, as many have noted.  One of my favorite beers to date.
bottle 330ml 7 shared at Kaunis Kampela with FatPhil& Anna 290908 hazy dark brown Taste Kick of sour and heavy fruity esters tickling carbonation hops bit sticky. Maybe need a re-rate.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Highly carbonated creates a great mouthfeel.  Reminiscent of a kinda sparkling little kids wine on new years kinda stuff on the nose.  A pleasant beer, but not incredible.

Stunning chestnut brown pour with luscious pillowy head.  Gorgeous.  Brandyish toffee, fruited nose with a green apple boozy cherry quality.  Vineous body with a figgy chewed yeast and salivating tartness developing mid to late palate.  Thies yeilds an earthy toasted fruit finish.  Layered flavors and nice complexity. All together this brew brings the funk sauce. ... Nice.

pours a very hazy orangish-brown with a massive foamy brown head.
dark fruit, light yeast, some sweet cola-ish caramel and molassess.
Mouthfeel is intensely carbonated at first.
Flavour is dark nutty malt, sweet again with a hint of cola going into a pretty tart finish. No sign of the 9%...
Sampled at Kelk in Brugge. Cloudy brown color.Dark fruitiness on the nose. Smooth on the palate. Molasses, almond nuttiness, and caramel malt. Some alcohol presence. Good complex brew.

Bottle into snifter. Pours a very hazy rich brown, with a fairly foamy, pillowy tan head. Nose is molasses, dark fruits, with just a hint of lactic sourness. Taste is phenomenal - caramelized sugar and molasses, bready yeast, with that beautiful, rich, full lactic sourness towards the back end. Hints of vinous dark fruits in there as well. Mouthfeel is very crisp and dry, medium bodied, crisp carbonation. Beautiful beer.
Pours amber and cloudy with a generous white head.  Smells of dark fruit, molasses, some spice.  Tastes of brown sugar, some raisins and dates, figs, pepper, touches of spiciness.

33cl bottle, spewed like a geyser when opened.  Pour a murky dark brown, with a big frothy, fluffy tan head.  Aroma of apple, dark fruits, brown sugar, spices, and alcohol.  Taste was initially sweet, then came a hint of tart/sour and a strong alcohol burn, a bit medicinal.  Mouthfeel was somewhat creamy, with fizzy carbonation.  Overall a very aromatic and tasty Belgian.  Great!

33cl bottle. Pours a dark, hazy brown with faint amber/orange highlights and a very thick, very fluffy, tan head that fades eventually into a thin, persistent disk of pocked, swirly tan. The aroma is thick with malt and yeast character - very characteristic De Dolle yeast flavors. The aroma has some complexity in there - mustiness, hints of herbal hops, sticky and thick caramel, toasty melanoidins, and a faint and interesting note of acid/sour. The flavor starts sweet and bready with lots and lots of sweet malts. It also features a brief faint of acid as in the nose - just enough to cut the sweetness without actually tasting acidic or sour. At mid-palate there are some faint notes of spices, some dark candi syrup, and subtle licorice. The bite of carbon dioxide slightly augments the perceived acidity. Dark caramel (hints of chocolate) seem to persist throughout all over the palate. There are subtle notes of earthy hops and subtle spice in there, too (and is that rye I taste? perhaps). The finish is full, sweet, and warming. It finishes with the same house character as in the aroma and tip of the tongue. The mouthfeel is full and very generously carbonated. The body is full enough to stand up to the thick carbonation without it feeling spritzy or over-carbonated. Overall, a very tasty beer that is quite full flavored and has some interesting character. I don’t think it’s quite as strong as some other De Dolle brews, but good nevertheless.

Couldn’t find a date on the bottle, but I’m wondering if it was a little old.  Beer opened with a huge hiss and when poured had a gigantic offwhite head that lasted forever.  Took about five minutes to pour the whole beer.

Aroma is a little apple, a lot of malt, some all spice?  Licorice, dark fruit.  A lot going on there.

Flavor is similarly complex, tart, a little bitter, a lot of alcohol burn.  Some nice subtle plum/raisin flavors with some good malt sweetness. A little bitter.  Tastes like it might be slightly oxidized, but not horribly.  Great beer.  I’d love to try another one fresh.
Brown, amber colored brew.Aroma is spicy, some fruits. Flavor is hoppy, nice bitterness and some spices.

Took me a while to find this one, but the wait was well worth it.  Typical spicy, malty, and sugary aroma and flavor.  As the beer moves across the palate, the flavor shifts from sweet to more of a sour/tart flavor.  Finish is sweet and sour as well.  Amazing beer.

Pours a hazy reddish brown with a big off white head. Some dark fruit in the aroma as well as spices, dark candi sugar almost port like. Flavor is complex dark fruit, port, spice roasted malt. Sweet yet sour in the finish. Yet another fine brew from the Mad Brewers.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 Another large de dolle head, this time beige on top of an opaque mahogany. The nose has some dark fruit, yeasty bubblegum, tripel spices, and most surprisingly, a large sour component. The flavor reflects the sour character and is quite tart with belgian malts, yeast, pepper, and cherry cough medicine, malt long in the aftertaste. With warmth theres a fantastically tart balance of sweet yet sour caramel and fruit. Medium-bodied and a little fizzy, this is a complex and intriguing beer.06/11 - 05 Spec Brew white cap pours dark red brown, thin cream ring. Nut and creamy, very oily chocolate reminds of fine dark chocolate, thin berry, bit date, quad-like, peppery finish to the flavor with a bit of citric. Very aged at this point, nearing port qualities with the oxidation. 737315

33 cl Bottle  found at Beer Paradise in Holstebro. Beautiful hazy red-brown color. Rather big beige head. Wood aromas along with spices and some raisins. Complex tastes of yeast, caramel, raisins. A wonderful complex beer

Bottle @ Café Gollem. Reddish brown colour with a big tan head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma of dark fruits, tart, spices and brown sugar. Flavour is initially sweet, then sour fruits, roasted malts, caramel, yeast. The sourness spoils it for me.
Amber reddish colour. Small white reddish head. A quite sour taste with some maltiness and spices.
Clear brown of color with a beige head. An aroma with spice, dark fruits, port and choclate hints. A flavor of dark fruits, spice, sweet liqurice and port.
Bottle (1991 I believe) at RBSG shared by HelloMyNameIs; Nose of Cherries, raisins, & yeast; Clear amber with a small beige head; Flavor very much dark fruits and yeastiness!

Bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a beautiful foamy head. Aroma sweet malts,  spices and yeast. The alcohol is present as well. Good mouthfeel as the beer kinda explodes in your mouth. Flavour is dark fruits, spices, alcohol and a bit tart.

A hazy brown colored beer, with a big foamy beige head. The aroma of dark sweet malts, yeast, some spices and fruits. The taste of caramel, dark dried fruits and alcohol. Tones of nuts and yeast. A little bitter aftertaste. A very good beer.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, good brew

Bottle from Sams in Chicago. Pours out an amazing thick cream colored head, I mean this gave me a pour with 90% head. The body is a fizzy light brown. The aroma is full of sweet candies and rich fruits. The taste was full of fruits; sour cherries, strawberries, also a massive chocolate and yeast balance. The body is fizzy and full. Some metallic and near bitter notes in the finish. Very well balanced, and so damn good. One of my favorite BSAs for sure. Just lovely.

Bottle...nice lacing...dainty but present...cloudy brown body with a tan head that has a dark tone to it...sweet yeast and a touch of cherries in the nose...initial mouth feel sweet, but the sugars seem real hearty--almost like brown sugar...a tartness to entire presence of this brew--light yet complex...I can dig it ...a little one dimensional , but good
its a gusher that pours with a giant rootbeer head. It settles at a moderate pace and does not go away fully. Aroma of ripe cheese and malt. Yeasty flavor and full boddied. Floral and tart.
Milk chocolate brown, seriously thick rootbeer float head. Sediment chillin on the bottom of my glass, some stuck in head. Dark toffee, malt, coffee notes.

12oz bottle. Incredible beer. Pours a golden color with a tall long lasting white head. As with all De Dolle, this was a gusher. Nose of spicy fruit, yeast and some awesome sour funkiness. Taste has some strong spicy peppery notes but no real hops in this one. Its got a very sweet finish with a nice tartness in the middle. Not much sour here but the funkiness of the yeast comes through in the tartness. Can’t wait to try the Reserva.

11.2oz bottle.  When I popped the cap foam slowly started to gush up the neck of the bottle.  Upon pouring the golden liquid created one of the foamiest, rockiest, biggest white heads Ive ever seen on a beer.  This thing gives Fantome a run for its money in the gigantic soapy heads that are so thick and firm they are like bubble bath I could apply to my face and make a beard that stays there category.  Lacing is awesome.  The aroma is nearly identical to Duvel.  That normal fruity, peppery, spicy, yeasty, estery Belgian golden ale smell.  Perhaps a touch of funk in there as well but I could be reaching.  Taste is dry, peppery, with a grainy, rough texture.  No sweetness or esters in the flavor.  I am a huge fan of the Special Reserve version of this beer so I was excited to try this.  This obviously is not nearly as good but I think it is one of the better examples of the style I have had.
Quite some carbonation with taste of caramel, citrus and malt all over. Rather nice with a medium thickness in the mouth and an ok sweet and aftertaste. I hopes in more complexity.

11.6oz bottle from World of Beer (Largo, FL). Pours a dark brown with one finger tan, frothy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet and spicy with notes of caramel, bread, yeast, yogurt. Flavor is initially sweet and sour that gives way to a burst of ripe fruit, tart, earthy and malt notes, and a lingering sweet, earthy finish. Medium-bodied.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2008 dark, redish amber ale with copious head. Cloudy with noticeable yeast. Fizzy and lively in the mouth. The aroma is difficult to describe, you could say it smells of oxide and sour apple candy.The predominant flavor is of green apples with some spices.There is a good balance of hops and sourness. This beer should belong in a category of it’s own, I have never tasted anything with a similar taste. A good beer nonetheless. B+

First of mine from De Dolle.  Lots of carbonation.  Hazy brown amber pour with a large fizzy head.  Lots of malt and sour darkfruit in the nose.  Flavor is a nice balance of bittersweet and sourness.  Smooth fizzy palate.  Impressive.

Bottle. Pours deep ruby brown with a beige head. Whiskey-like aroma with dark fruit, plum and wood. Medium body. Flavor is a brilliant balance of dark sour fruits and woodiness. Sourness is pronounced, but restrained. Very nice.

Bottle.  I didnt enjoy this in any length as much as the reserva.  Pours an amber cloudy body with a big off white head.  Aroma is sweet and malty in the flavor as well.  Then woodiness but what ruins the funk for me is the hoppiness that come in to dominate the finish.  I could do without all this.

11.2 oz bottle from Stumpies in Gainesville.  This is my 3rd De Dolle beer.  Very impressive.  These guys could probably ferment owl pellets and it would at least be palatable.  Flavor of strong caramel and red apple.  Some hoppy bite at the end.  Not DDs best, but very good.

Bottle.  This was my first De Dolle brew Ive ever tried, and it wasnt disappointing. It pours a dark amber color and has a sweet malty aroma backed by caramel and yeast. 
It has a similar flavor and great mouth feel with its heavy carbonation.

First De Dolle Ive had that wasnt a gusher, but the carbonation was still plentiful, pouring a nice amber-tinted off white head on top of a deep bright reddish amber hazy pour.  Yeast, malt, bread, intense and complex candied fruit and brown sugar on the nose and even more so on the palate. Would love to taste this aged a few years, though the intensity it has now is really lovely.

Appearance: red brown color. Great beige head, some rocky, not much dense and very lasting.
Aroma: yeasty, mainly, and caramel and dark malts smells. Candy, sugary and liquory/vinous touches. The yeast puts banana and vanilla aromatic reminiscences; other fruit smells like raisins, figs and plums.
Flavor: caramel and semi-toasted malts start, some sweet, with a very intensive yeasty progress. Enough alcoholics hints. Fruity reminiscences like banana, raisins in rum and candy oranges. Light woody notes. Final with liquory dryness and cognac reminiscences. Yeasty and candy aftertaste. 
Palate: medium body and velvety texture. Medium to high natural carbonation.
Remark: beer without the complexity that I hoped, maybe with more age could be a marvelous. An excessive yeasty taste.

Bottle at home ... Lovely scarlet red ... nice firm off white  head ... week sweet liquorice nose ... Fizzy slightly tart sour ... definite nip on the tongue as Linus_Stick said ... liquorice in linger ... It foams in the mouth .. which in a lot of ways hides the flavour ... a little grapefruit dryng in linger

A very good and different Belgian strong. Aroma was very weak. Started out as sulfur, but never really came out at all. Near odorless. Pour was perfect. Deep dark red/near brown with lovely sediment and a huge puffy tan head that you could rest a penny on. Taste was very yeasty and bitey. Strong brown sugar, yeast and caramel malt with the sediment lending a smoothness. Strong carbonation that works with the yeast to nip and the tongue and cheeks. Nice beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 33cl bottle, nice pillowy head. Some bubblegummy esters, mild licorice (anise), dark cane sugar aroma. Rich, sweet malt flavor, bready, brown sugary, licorice/molasses, alcohol wafts through the nostrils. Medium hop bitterness is present, finish is medium duration, some sweetness but dries out at the end. Nice beer but not my cup of tea

Bottle.  Pours a murky dark brownish amber with a large lasting bubbly white head. Strong and very sweet aroma of yeast, sugar and caramel malt.  The taste is quite sweet as well with a load of candied sugar and enough sourness to make your tongue tingle.  Lots of caramel malt along with fruit, yeast and pretty strong alcohol presence.  Medium bodied with strong carbonation and a sugary sweet, almost syrupy mouthfeel.  I actually prefer this slightly to the Reserve, very nice.

bottle from beersofeurope.co.uk great website with quick service and great range of beer impossible to get in this desert known as glasgow. pours brown hazy with a resistant foamy head. nose is cherry, cheese, slight berry, very sweet smelling, strawberry apple. complex but not very strong. fizzy light mouthfeel. tastes bitter, slightly treebark. strong alcohol warming throughout. maybe too harsh. very good, bu the reserve rules on this.
Bottle: pours a hazy, redish-brown with a big foamy tan head, aroma is slightly sweet and malty, taste is dark fruits, malt, a bit sour, some warming alcohol in the finish.  Very nice.

Pours brown in color with a ginormous head.  Took a long time to pour because I had to wait for the head to die down far enough to pour the rest in.  Smell is dark fruits and some tartness.  Taste is much the same with a nice yeasty flavor as well.  Creamy and wonderful on the mouthfeel.  I can only imagine what the Reserve tastes like.  Have yet to have a disappointing beer from De Dolle.

Bottle 33 cl. Complex in aroma and flavor with a sour finish after a sweet beginning (Sweet Tarts). Big off-white frothy head and a hazy amber body. Aroma start musty and opens to caramel, cherry, cinnamon, bitter chocolate. The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately bitter and moderately acidic. Very bitter/tart/sour finish  like tart cherry juice. But tastes of plum, raisin and toffee emerge underneath the tartness. Medium  body, watery texture and lively carbonation.
33 cl bottle. Brown color, very big beige head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Flavor is sweet malt, some sourness and fruit.

Bottled. A hazy brown beer with a huge beige head. Aroma is very alty and sweety, notes of spices. Taste is also very malty, lots of spices and notes of yeast. Alcoholic, notes of caramel and toffee. Salt and tart finish.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 (Re-rate on 2008-09-15)

(Bottle at Hilpeä Hauki on 2008-09-15) Amber colour. Large white head. Sour and malty nose. Full bodied palate with quite lot of carbonation. Sourness, bitterness, malts, salty liquorice and bitterness in taste.

------ l bottle at Staminee de Garre, Brugge, on 2008-05-18)  Amber/red colour. Slightly red head with some bubbles. Hazy. Sourish nose with some malts. Acidic palate, medium body, some dryness. Sweetish and somewhat sour taste. Some hops. Fruity. (Rating 3.6)

2008 Bottle - Aroma is pure strawberries and grains, beautiful red colour with a huge off-white head, yeasty, fruit, tobacco, and incredibly sour, tannic, alcohol is present but not overt, I really just dont care much for it...

Reading Beer Festival 2 May 08. Ruby red colored. Flaky. A shortlived fluffy head. Aroma of sweet fruits. Sparkling. Strong sweet flavor with a fruity aftertaste. Alcohol well hidden. Warming. Quite good.

We rounded off our drinking session at the 14th Reading Beer and Cider festival with a few bottles from De Dolle found in the foreign beers section. This one poured a clear mahogany body under a tan, foamy head. Aroma of brown sugar with notes of malt and yeast. Rich in flavour with caramel sweetness blended by dried and dark fruits. Yeast and smooth alcohol beneath. Good mouthfeel (shared with Finn, 02.05.2008).

This was a little tart and sour at first, but then some of the sweeter maltiness comes through as it warms.  Lots of fruitiness, with some minerality and woody notes coming through as well.  Does nto have a lot of depth and complexity, but it does have a strange drinkability to it.

Pours murky brown with large white head.  Looks really good in my trappists glass.  Fruity, sweet, caramel notes in the aroma.  A quality brew well balanced in flavor and not to overpowering.  I can see that this will turn to a wine with some age.  I can taste a wine/wood with a tart aftertaste that makes me want more.

dark brown with large tan head.  flavor is of caramal malt with candy sugar present.  the beer is powerful but doesnt really develop the complexity and depth i had expected.  the finish is a little sour.  i feel as though this beer could have aged a few years to become something

First impression: Very carbonated. Even though my bottle had been standing still for about two months before I opened it it squirted like a well shocken bottle of champagne. Second impression: Smells nice, very floral, lots of fruit (passionfruit, cherries and more). Amber, and hazy (maybe more so due to the comotion of the opening). Taste is malty, fresh and cherryish - lots of acidity. A prominent tartness. The alcohol is not very evident. I cant quite put my finger on it but there is something that seems to be missing in the experience of this beer. Good indeed, but Ive had better.

Aroma is a fantasic floral, with sour notes, and some yeast along with a fantasic apple aroma.
A Beautiful big head tops a gorgeous deep amber ale. 
Taste is delicous and malty, very complex with notes of sour cherries, roasted malt, apple, some delicous winey oak flavors, with light hop bitterness and a faint musty yeast flavor. 
Palate is very different, it is quite creamy but the sourness keeps it sharp.

Dark amber with a huge untamable head. Definitely sweet, vinous, peppery, with a light sirupy fruitiness, such as cherries. caramel. Quite ethylic MF, complex, rich maltiness and that typical Dolles tartness.

Bottle, Beers of Europe. Bottle. Pours a reddy brown colour with a foaming dissipating off-white head. Aroma is sweet and rich-:malty, chocolate, coffee and molasses. Smooth tasting, full bodied flavour with more malt, raisin, and some spiciness. A sophisticated fella this, complex and well worth seeking out.

Dark brown hazy appearance with a delisicious beige head. Strong fruity and toffee nose. The taste is very complex with some dried fruits, chocolate, some tart and a powerful roasted flavour. Long roasted aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2008 Bottle from the Dolle. Pours dark brown almost black with a ruby shade when held to a light.
Head is creamy beige tanwhite.
Nose is typical candyshop sweetness with hints of all sorts of fruits.
Aroma is definitely roasted toast, cofee with small hints of cough drop and soy sauce. Aftertaste is filled with yeast. Flavor is bitter and sweet but the bitter takes the lead eventually.
Tonguefeel could have been a bit better but overall a very good brew.

[Bottle, thanks Guerde] Pours hazy reddish-brown with a big beige head that quickly dies down but doesnt disappear. Aroma is fruity (a little plum, maybe), some alcohol, yeast. Taste is a little tart up front, then some grape and yeast which slowly fades into a finish that has what seems like very subdued smokiness, a little chocolate and more yeast. Medium mouthfeel with a long finish. Another good De Dolle beer.

(bottle) Pours a chestnut brown with a large light tan head that retains nicely.  Aroma is very dry, with smells of yeast, cocoa, vinous, slight candi sugar, and theres a hint of cherry skin tartness as well that lurks in the background.   Quite an unique flavor of dried fruit and dark chocolate, which yields to an interesting tart, yeasty, and lightly roasted finish.  A very different beer, but in a good way.

Pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of plums, raisins, caramel, toffee, and alcohol.  Excellent flavor of dark fruits, brown sugar, and carlamel with string vineous notes. Dry and sweet on the finish.  Very nice Belgian.

Color: Murky brown, cloudy with foamy brown head and light lacing. 

Nose: Amazing sweet wine notes. Port-like on second pass. Heavy rancio, almost becomes cognac-like. Cinnamon, clove and caramel. Rich, fudgey oak. 

Palate: Dry sherry and Cognacais notes. heavy caramel, oxidized oak, firm tannins. Very dry and very rich. Old raisin, prune, rancio, dry, spicy, kiln-dried oak. Succulent finish. Sweet and rich. An after dinner beer.

bottle from bottleshop off grand place. dark amber pour, nice sustained head with good lacing.  Roasted malt dominates...a hit of sourness in the finish.  I like everything Ive tried from this brewer.

33cl - Aroma is yeasty and malty.  Rusty water and subtle spice.  Pours very dark brown with a huge head and great lacing.  Flavor has more roasted malts but is otherwise very similar to the aroma.  Strong alcohol.  Palate is sticky and hot.  Reading the reviews, I guess I needed to sit on this one for a few years.

(3/2/08) Bottle (I think) sample at Zythos Bier Festival 2008 in Sint Niklaas. Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, dark fruits and some alcohol. Sweet flavor with malt, caramel, soft fruitiness and a dry finish with some alcohol burn. Medium to full body with lots of carbonation.
scura ottima schiuma persistente sentori tostati speziati lieve acidulo in bocca caffe tostato morbida retrogusto acidulo

A dark brown pour with a light tan head and lace. Aroma of brown sugar or molasses Im not sure. A flavor of brown sugar laced with abv. Carbonation is a bit over the top for me, but the flavor of brown sugar and abv are right down my alley. The complexity goes beyond that but that is where my fried palate cries uncle. A very good beer that Im glad did not come in a 22ozer or I would be toast.

Aarhus
Bottled
Complex malt flavour that hides the alcohol well
Bitterness rather low
Mahogani  with a fruity aroma of pinneapple and nuts. The flavour starts out a bit acidity and procedes into hazel nuts, coffee and bread. Very nice.
Bottled. Pours a super dark, almost opaque brown. I liked it but could have used a bit more sweetness.  Tastes almost wine-ey? MOre age? who knows.

Overflows immediately upon opening, and it takes a good 10 minutes to pour. But it sure looks nice with that tower of foam over the rim of the glass. Smells like an oatmeal raisin cookie, plus some rrum or other alcohol heat. Flavor is a lot of alcohol, plus the aforementioned oatmeal raisin cookie. Lots of intriguing flavors, but the alcohol is persistant, and distracting. Decent now, would like to age one and see what happens.

the palate of this beer is so complex every time take a sip you can dicover other flavors.
This dark beer is rich and the smell is olso verry good

UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 [Rated 3.18.2008] Pours darker reddish brown with a large foamy beige head that fades into a creamy forth.  Delicious malty, woody, toffee aroma.   Sweet rich molasses malt, vinous, somewhat tangy/sour with a bitter woody finish.  Very lively vacant mouthful, too vacant, detracts from the flavor (smoothes out after 15 minutes of sitting open).  Considering how rich the flavor is, I wish it was a little fuller in body.  Similar to Pannepot Danish edition.  Could definitely use another year + of aging.  9.5.8.4.17

[Rerate 4.17.09]  Pours a dull opaque  reddish dark brown with a thick frothy beige head 4.5.  Fantastic rich malty nutty aroma, slightly vinous.   Sweet nutty first taste, very authentically trappist, yesty, darker candi sugar, pretty rich but more towards cloying and sugary,  noticeable hops, some citrus like juiciness, woody cheesy finish with a bitter aftertaste 8.5.   Medium bodied, slightly chewy, larger abundant fluffy sharp carbonation.  "Age me" this says.   9.5.8.4.17

Bottle 33 cl. As any other dolle you hardly get the cap off before the beer shows it self. (Remember a tissue).A medium body where you clearly sense the alcohol and burned malts and wood. The nose is quite light with hints of rusty water and sour fruits. The head is thick and lasts all the way.

11.5oz bottle into tulip glass. poured creates a thick sticky head with a light brown color foam. beer color is dark brown and almost opaque. scent was sweet of cherries and raisins. sips of strong alcohol that burns after a few seconds, almost like a whiskey. subsides a bit as it warms. flavors of apple and caramel washes over pallette. overall a good beer, but potent.

From a goblet. Huge, dense, finely bubbled head over a murky reddish brown body. A great initial nose of plum, raisin, and spice. The flavor is caramel and fruit with some yeasty spiciness. The sharpness of the carbonation detracts from the flavor until it dissipates. Towards the end of the glass, the tart, woody qualities take over on the aroma and flavor with a touch of bitterness.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with huge beige head and very active carbonation. The aroma is mellow and sweet, with caramel, various fruits, a slight vinous note, and a touch of spicy alcohol. The flavor is full of dark fruits. Plum, raisin, even a little bit of black cherry hit the mouth first, then a soft caramel sweetness. A distant woodiness gives just a little bit of bitterness. The finish is slightly dry and rather vinous, but quickly melds into an aftertaste full of golden toast. All of the flavors here meld so gracefully into one another, and everything is nicely rounded. This is quite a well-made brew.

This one climbed out of the 33 cl bottle from Monument in Concord, CA. Rich, dark yeast and fruit aromas. Spicey. Dark mahogany color with an active tan head. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Something like a light oporto flavor with heavy bread. Yeast spice all over with notes of raisin and prune. Not to mention caramel. Finish has some oak hints, and is rather surprisingly dry. Very pleasurable concoction.

Caramel colored with a fleeting khaki crown. Medium strength sweet, yeasty candy sugar earthy aroma. Dusty dark malt taste at first sip with spices and a light pit fruit sweetness to finish.  Underwhelming. 6107
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 11.6oz bottle.  Pours a bright, slightly hazy cherry-wooden color; huge, light tan head with great retention and medium-bubbled lacing; a gorgeous pour.  Excellent yeasty and dark fruit aroma, if slightly reserved: lots of yeast, cherry syrup, and slightly tart cherry and citrus; Id love to see this with some age behind it.  Full mouthfeel: dried red and dark fruits, chewy caramel and candy sugar, with an intricate yeast character serving to dry most of everything out; again, this would be beautiful with more age; tons of flavor encompassed by a warming, toasty yeastiness and alcohol and red fruitiness, brought together carefully; I would adore this beer even more if the sweetness were toned down slightly and a bit of tartness were included (cellaring will do this wonders).  Lengthy finish, showing loads of red fruits, candy sugar, and the De Dolle yeastiness.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a murky brown with a small head and brown sugar and ripe fruits in the nose. Full sweet flavor of raisin, ripe fruits, caramel, candy sugar and honey. Sweet finish with a little bitterness. Good one

Poured from a 33cl bottle and served in a tulip.  This beer poured a muddy, dark brown with a thick, fizzy head of tan foam that lasted throughout the entire glass.  Not much lace.  The aroma of the beer was typical for a dark Belgian and was made up of ripened dark fruit, candi sugar, some doughy yeast, and just a touch of alcohol.  The flavor consisted of dates, raisins, red apples, mild caramel, candi sugar, and some tongue warming alcohol.  The mouthfeel was medium to full-bodied with moderately aggressive carbonation.  Not a bad beer, but a bit boring.  For a style that is commonly produced, there is much better available.

Pours a cloudy Brown with a creamy tan head.  Lots of carbonation bubbles are apparent and the head has excellent retention.  Aroma of fruits, malt, yeast, rasins. Flavor of fruit, caramel, banana, spices, yeast.Slightly bitter yet sour finish.
Pours a dark brown with a large good looking tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and some belgian yeast. Tart, sweet. Quite a bit of carbonation.

This goes into a tulip with lots of sediment. It is a cherrybrownish color. An inch of creamy head crowns the beer. The nose is of malty spices, and maybe some yeast or earthiness. 

My first sips of this at cellar temperature were not pleasant. From reading the reviews, I know that the tart, somewhat sour flavor is normal. I just dont care for it. I could actually say that I like this as it nears room temperature. The sourness is gone, although it is still tart. The flavor is refreshing, and complex. I can taste the Belgian yeast, maybe some sour apples, biscuity malt, and grassy hops. 

The mouthfeel is thick without being syrupy in the slightest. The drinkability is low, not because I dont like this, but the flavors would become cloying. I could probably have another one, though. IMO, pop this at cellar temperature just to taste it in that state. As for me, the next time I will start drinking this one at a warmer temperature. This has quite the finish.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-22-2005 06:00:33

Pours dark brown with a thick fluffy and sturdy tan head. Aromas are a complex melange of malts, bready yeast, and bananas, some coffee and alcohol. Flavour is full bodied with brown-sugary, molasses-laden malt, caramel and milk chocolate, raisins and a throat-warming alcohol. Finish is soft and fruity, although zestily bitter.

I think Ryan brought this to PP bottle shop.  Thanks!  Darkish amber color.  Strong carbonation burns the tongue.  Phenolic plastic De Dolle aroma.  Do they finish their beers with Brett?  Pretty decent.  A little malty and sweet.  Maybe a little tart.

Its good, but a taste I have not fully acquired.  Bottle at Stuffed Sandwich.  A real light-spectrum classic, with only faint notes that sharpen to a darker-than-geuzy tang at the end.  Raisins, nuts, tart green apple, flour and caramel are all a good guess, but far from the overall impact.  A good beer to grow on.

Poured dark amber/brown with a big tan head. Sweet aroma of sugars, raisins, cherries. Flavor is sour and tart. Medium body with fizzy carbonation and a bitter, metallic finish. A decent beer but not my thing.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 Bottled, shared at the PP Bottle Shop with wetherel, DenverLogan, goldtwins, Ryan and Sean. Lovely appearance once poured, a clear dark copper color with an initial big frothy head and sticky lacing. Great intriguing aromas! I had some trouble just trying to pick out the right words. Scents of Belgian yeasts, banana fruitcake with raisin and plum. The flavor follows the aromas well with notes of sweet caramelized bananas, cherry-chocolate and an interesting dark vinous character. Finishes tart and faintly sour with citrus and some sting.

Deep coffee brown with a huge tan large bubbled head. Lots of little floaties swimming around in the glass. Aroma is very diverse with tart cherries, herbs, dough, caramel, raisins, figs and a bit of alcohol. The flavor is roasted malt, sour, chocolate, berries and just a hint of bret. Long tart bitter finish. Medium bodied, sticky texture.

July 2006 - Hard beer to review. Amazingly complex in aroma and flavor. Beautiful pour with lacing literally stuck to the glass. Earthy flavors with dark fruit, a smoky chicory flavor, sour cherries and an alcohol burn. Put all that together and on paper, its fantastic. For some reason I just wasnt digging it all that much. It seemed like an amazingly crafted brew, just didnt appeal to me

33cl bottle: Pours a lightly hazy, deep rusty brown with nice red edges and an average tan top. Aroma is full of refreshingly tart summer berries, herbs, lots of yeast, caramel, raisins, light alcohol, and a slightly soapy character. Once it passes the lips you get an explosion (from the high CO2) of yeast, malt, and a "green" herbal sting. Berries come in the middle followed by a long dry herbal and metallic finish. Alcohol comes through more and more as you make your way down the glass.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2008 Hazy brown with a froathing baige head lasting all the way through. Aroma is extremly alchoholic in a very nice vinouse way with sonme sour celler notes. Flavor is strong and intense, feels like your mouth is getting a cleaning. Again strong alchohol notes, bitter and very very warming. Nice sipping beer.

Bottle. Very sweet malty, very yeasty. Off-white large creamy head, long lasting. Very dark brown colour. Moderate sweet start, light acetic, average duration. Medium body, dry and creamy, lively carbonation. Light alcoholic and metallic finish.
Beautiful dark beer with good head. Malty, sour aromas but when you taste it...wow a lovely dubbel. Carbonated but smooth and tasty. Delicious

Bottle, from Holiday Wine Cellar.   Surprisingly dark pour - a deep amber/bronze color.  Aroma is kind of sour, leading me to think "uh oh", but this was surprisingly smooth and tasty.  There is definitely some light brett in the mix, but this is a mildly sour beer, at best.    Kind of reminds me of Orval.  Its nobodys Teve, but its damn nice.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2009 330ml bottle-A hazy dark amber body with a nice loose tan head that dissipated into a small covering.  Aroma of roasted malt, fruity, sourness, tartness, and yeast. A full bodied brew that comes across with champagne like carbonation and malt and fruit coming out. The alcohol is hidden real well. Nice tasting brew.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2010 Bottled. A hazy dark amber beer with a huge, frothy, lacing, mostly lasting beige head. The aroma is moderately malty and lightly yeasty, with notes of toasted grains, caramel, cherries, dark fruits, berries, spices and a hint of alcohol. The flavour is moderately sweet, moderately sour, lightly bitter. Medium body, slick texture, lively carbonation, long finish with light to medium bitterness, lightly alcoholic. More sour than the last time I had it, complex with well balanced spiciness, seducing look with almost no alcohol feel. It seems better after every sip.

330ml bottle at Microbar, Clapham, 14th Jan 08. Ruby chestnut colour with a small head. Strong aroma of sweet malt, blackcurrant and sour raspberry. Flavour is similar but with caramel malt coming through too. Smooth with a warming finish. Fantastic beer all round!

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2009 Caramel colored and murky with a huge white head. Very highly carbonated. Big fruity nose with touches of caramel, toffee and figs. Flavor is much the same: sharp, earthy and sweet. Very good.

Bottle.   Pours a cloudy brown color with a decent sized beige colored head.   Aroma is sweet caramel, some fruity esters, raisins.   Flavor is caramel, dried fruits, yeast, alcohol.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished lightly bitter with some alcohol warmth.
Bottle: Pours a murky brown with a medium fizzy tan head. Aroma, sweet fruity notes, caramel, some spice. Flavor, sweet, green apples, tart, some doughy notes, spices. Floral hops on the finish.
11.6 oz bottle.  Dark red-brown color.  Very thick head.  Real sour fruity aroma.  Apple tones.  Bitter, slightly sour taste.  Sweet at first.  Very fruity.  Hops on the end.  Very good.

Bottle: Deep red clear colour, with a werry nice creamy head. Aroma of caramel, fruity,chocolate and a bit citric in the end.
Flavor has almost the same, sparkling feeling in the mouth, medium to full body, medium caramely/bitter finish. This is a werry nice belgian strong ale.
Totally opaque brown color with a nice creamy tan head.  Smells like rusted iron or blood which isnt so hot, but it tastes pretty good with a nice twist -- kind of corky, woody and bitter.

Pours a brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is slight roasted malts, molasses, dark fruit, and caramel malts.  Flavor is the same with a slightly bitter finish of the citrus hops.  Overall this was pretty good.

(bottle): Pours a reddish brown color, maybe cloudy. Small tannish head, not as lasting. Aroma of dark fruit, raisins, dark fruit. Sickly sweet. Dark fruit taste. Carbonated, sweet. Vinegary. Good taste, not too complex.

Pours a cloudy brown with a thin, though bright white head.  The aroma is fermenting fruit mixed with high-sugar malts and a sour note.  The flavor is very interesting.  Starts off strongly sweet for an instant and then a sour cherry note comes through that cleanses the palate and washes away any stickiness that might have been left by the heavy malts.  Its strangely as if you as drinking more than 1 beer.  Finishes clean after the tart washout on the palate.  Overall, an incredibly interesting and complex BSA.

Hazy dark brown with medium off white head. Sweet malty flavor with toffee, overripe fruits and yeast. Sweet flavor with malt, toffee and overripe fruits. Some sour notes as well. Good comlexity and nice balance. Alcohol well hidden.

Bottle 33 cl. Dark brown, hazy and tan foam thats mostly disappearing. Full body, thick feel, lively. Aroma of chocolate and dried fruit. The finish is long, dominated by alcohol and is lightly bitter and lightly sour.

Somehow Ive never rated this, even though I love De Dolle stuff.  Deep ruby, wispy shockingly white head.  Nose is caramel & alcohol, dark fruits, cocoa and yeast, plum and tobacco.  A bit hot but still very nice.  Flavor is huge caramel & dark fruit, bubblegum, rich concord grapes, cocoa, cherries, caramelized raisins.  A hint of smoke in the finish.  Its good but it lacks something to tie it all together - I want either higher carbonation, some tartness or 15 years of age on this bottle.

Pours a murky brown with orange highlights and a massive puffy tan head that fizzles to  a sudsy film. The aroma is full of fruity esters and sour yeast, possibly brett yeast? Nuts, earthy hops and candi sugar also grace the aroma. There are dominant suggestions of tropical fruit, though the nose is relatively muted. A caramel backbone is also present. The flavour is cider-like with tart fruits coming from the yeast and a dry, floral and fragrant finish. As it warms, the booze presence is amplified. There are some unpleasant rotten, sour bile-like hints in the finish as well.  Nice velvety texture, but the finish is a bit sour and metallic.

2005 bottle / 11.2 oz - Pours very dark ruby red with a tight tan head. The aroma has lots of rich caramel that is smooth and rich, toffee, light Belgium earthiness ~ doesnt come across as complex as Id thought it would, but it is quite nice.  Medium body thats quite crisp with sharp carbonation that doesnt interfere with the flavors.  The flavor starts with a mix of rich caramel, rich berries, funky yeastiness, biscuit and a variety of spices.  The flavor is far more complex that the aroma suggested.  The finish is spicy, funky and tart.  Great beer.

0.33 l bottle. Hazy mahagony color, very fizzy. Acidic, yeasty, meaty, caramelly, berryish, perfumed and spicy aroma with notes of pepper, vanilla, almonds, leather, prunes and raisins. Dryish yeasty and berryish flavor with some 
dull and grassy hops as well as woody notes. Very heavy disturbing carbonation.
Not a big fan.  A sour alcohol taste.  Is not hoppy, not thick and stouty, not fruity. Just pungent tasting dull.

The aroma offered by this beer is an infusion of yeast, dates, and alcohol. It is a light cocoa colored solution that sits under a thick off-white head. This beer is heavy and thick as it enters the mouth. The taste is a combination of wheat, dates, yeast, nuts, and citrus fruit hidden in the background. The aftertaste is a mild nutty one that lingers well.

Wow, another masterpiece by De Dolle. Nutmeg and sour apples in the nose. Very lively carbonation that fills up the body. Pours thicker than most imperial stouts and looks beautifully like impenetrable shoe polish in the glass. Tastes very fruity, very rotten-citrus spicy. Absolutely fantastic.

Dark mahogany pour, medium white head that fades but lasts. Aroma is belgian yeast all the way, some sour notes, fruits, brandy. Flavor is much the same slight sour notes, brandy, and lots of spicy yeast. Sugary sweet but not cloying. Tons of carbonation but with a thing mouthfeel. A touch of chocolate way in the background with the fruit and brandy just ruling this beer. Complex but not a great tasting beer.

Pours translucent chocolate-brown with first-fizzy, then-creamy tan head.  Aroma is sour with notes of raisin, apple, maple, brown sugar, and, like the last reviewer has stated, a hint of chocolate-covered mint (good call on that).  Flavor is nicely sour with notes of spicy apple cider, raisin, grape, and a hint of yeast.  Palate is fairly creamy but also sustains a dry finish.  Impressive.

33 cl. Cloudy, turbulent chocolate-brown beer with a large, lasting head. Aroma is brown sugar, sour leather, and sweet herb, akin to a mild chocolate-covered mint. Flavors of rum, raisin, sour toffee, salty leather, and maybe some earthy peppery spice (wait, maybe thats  the carbonation and alcohol instead). Strong alcohol finish. Dryish, with a highly carbonated, airy mouthfeel thats annoying; seems like it might be almost medium-bodied if it would stop fizzing.
this bottle may have been a little off - dark amber with small head.  Tons of yeast oozing....not my favorite De Dolle...will have to re-rate

Bottle at the man who was too louds house. Aroma let down because I had just eaten a chinese. Not the beers fault. Still had to bargain with myself that a 7 for aroma would do, only if I bumped up the score elsewhere. Maybe i will, maybe I wont. If I dont Ill beat myself over it. This has too many complex flavours for me to name. I will do anyway, cinnamon type smells, like the collar of my grey jacket, like the silver thing at work,like that there that smelled similar, like thingys old perfume when it wore off and you could smell her and that other smell. Very very nice, maybe slighlty tart but who the hell am I to say thats a bad thing?

Bottle, Gollem, Amsterdam.  Its much like their other beers.  Sweet, peppery, smooth as silk and finishes with a delicious yeast bomb.  Not the yeast in the bottle, im just talking flavor.  Delicious beer.
Pours a deep reddish/brown with a dense off white head, nose of yeasty fruit (apples) and cinnamon, sour tart flavor that show a lot of spice, malty/sweet/sour finish.

Bottle courtesy of Knightly Spirits. Pours a massive, close-to-volcanoing, off-white head over a dark mahogany body. Head sustains well over a couple minutes. Subtle aromas of yeast, soap, and wheat. Sweet and malty, overtones of sour barnyard hay, white wine, slight toast, bubblegum. Highly carbonated and full-bodied. Sweet malts and sour are close to equilibrium. Good beer, like most everything De Dolle brews.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Bottle.  Pours out a sediment filled dark brown, shows copper at the edges of the glass.  Creamy light tan head that laces.  Aroma is nice, fruity, yeast, notes of cranberry.  Potent flavor, sugar sweet, but not cloying with a spicy bitter finish.  Foamy medium body.

Re-rated 03/08/2009 - Consistent with the first rating, picked up a slightly tart/sour finish.  Great beer.

33 cL bottle. Pours deep reddish with a crispy and dense slight orange head. Aroma is dark malty, sweet and complex yeasty spiced. Heavy carbonation. Strong fruity and alcohol lifted initial flavour.
