wow another beautiful Belgian beer.A nice brownish red color with a huge head.Has a spicy but fruity taste.The alcohol kind of creeps up on you.Cant say anymore just another fine brew from the belgians

Massive head and sparkling carbonation. The color is ruby brown. The smell is sour, yeasty and contains apple notes. The flavor is medium sweet with butterscotch, apple and caremel and with very fresh and light earthy yeasts Absolutely wonderfully delicious. The sour smell is deceiving as it is barely detectable in the flavor. Well done.
Golden brown witha little mahagany coloring. Sopay like foam head. Smell of strong spices. Very strong smell. Not impressed. Good taste though. Strong at first and then smooth and mellow. Good beer.
Tons of light toffee colored head on this one. Yeasty, slightly winey aroma. Alcohol is very muted in the flavor, very nicely shifting from plums to cherries with an interesting yeast character.

Head: finger-wide root beer head, like A&W after a few minutes in the car.  Not your belgian lace, but not necessary with a brew this viscous and vinous in character.  Aroma: rather muted, faintly of japanese plums, cloves.  Appearance: deep, hazy mahogany, like a well-worn holly sole in a sailboat.  Flavor: this is where the action is with this brew.  Green raisins, cherry pie, spicy mincemeat, yeasty malt, some black pepper.  Palate: vinous, viscous.    Excellent red wine replacement.  Alcohol not too strong.  Well-balanced.  Odd creature on label.  Mysterious bow around neck.  For some reason, this beer reminds me of eating scones with strawberry jam at this roadside cafe off highway 101 in California near San Luis Obispo.  Go figure...

Poured a hazy/foggy amber/mahogony color with a 1 finger tan head. Aromas of spices, plums, caramel, yeast and raisins. Tastes of of brown sugar, molasses, sweet and malty. Complex smells and tastes that work very well.

Tried a single bottle of this. Poured reddish with a small short lasting head that had some funky chunks mixed into the head....Bad? Flavor was both dry and sweet...cherries? but almost all alcohol. Finish was acidic with yet more alcohol. I need to try this again....

Murky dark orange/brown color with a massive creamy off white colored head that is retained.  Aroma is very interesting.  Definite vinous aroma with some barleywine like aged aroma.  Very yeasty aroma also.  Flavor is big, bold and strong.  Im getting a big coffee finish which is a major shock.  Initial flavor is like bordeux, but the roasted malt in the finish totally through me.  Wasnt expecting that at all.  Very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2004 It had a wine like taste. I like Belgian strongs although this was a bit cloyingly sweet when first sipped. As it warmed the magic of the flavor came out and it was quite nice. It is a attractive red color with a vinorus scent. Very strong and a good beer allround though I find Chimey red and Duvel a better brew.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2011 So three of the last tnree were overcarbonated or infected. A common de dolle problem.  One of my fav brewers is now in my never buy classification.  It hurts.     







Wow!  Where has this beer been my whole life!  I wish I found it sooner!

Pour was amber/brown with nice off-white head.  Aroma is sweet yeast, slight overripened cherry?

Taste is superb, on the sweet side with layers and layers of complexity going on.  As it warms, it keeps changing, sweet but not cloying.
A must have, I am going back for more!

6yr old bottle. Muddy brown with initially big light brown head, myseriously fading into a 1cm foam, which sticks well. Nose is vinous with vinegar and oak-aged oud bruin suggestions. As the pour had indicated, there's plenty of yeast in there, but also a profound malt depth of apples, lactic cherry yogurt, blood oranges and a sweetness closing to milk chocolate. Appealing complexity already, but further sniffs have even more to offer with hints of earth, oak and saw dust. Medium bodied and sparkling, initially cherry/apple sweet, but balanced by more sourness than expected. Aftertaste can't hide the age of the sample, a little off-flavour of something alike cement or dirty grass distracts a bit from the enjoyment. I'm gonna try a fresher sample soon and make up conclusions on this aspect, but besides this, it is obviously a radious beer that fits my personal tastes with great class.

Nice beer... Dark brown color, with hints of dark red and orange colors. Beautiful off-white head.. thick and cramy... ummmm... Dark fruits, apple, caramel, molasses hit the nose, very balanced and complex. This is truely a mo-fo of a beer... The flavor is very nice... full, candied fruits, some sour notes... Complex and very enjoyable... De Dolle... mmmmmmm....

Pours a dark reddish brown  with a thick off white head. Aroma is fruity and malty. Nice full and chewy mouthfeel. Plum, cherry, yeast, and chocolate. Nice long and lingering after taste.  There's a lot going on with this beer. A great Belgian ale. De Dolle makes some great beer.

De Dolle Brouwers truly live up to their name. These mad men have created a beer that seems to defy all the rules. The color is a deep copper to plum. In the aroma I detect apple, syrup, and candi all of which come through in the flavor as well. This monsterous beer has a realativly light body with little mouthfeel, somewhat thin and vinous. The flavors are numerous and complex lending some sour, acidic notes mixed with fruit, syrup, and a dry oak finish. I have had the pleasure of tasting several vintages of this beer in the past, they tend to lay down well. The 2002 special Oerbier seems to be at its prime in 20004 yet could only mellow with a little more age.

bottle...pours a murky reddish brown with a large tan head that lingers.  In the foam, you can see the spent yeast.  Very malty aroma, with hints of fruitiness.  Lots of carobonation hit my tongue to begin with, followed by an intense sweetness which starts to burn with spiciness and alcohol.  The finish is sweet also, this is a fairly complex and delicious beer.

Pours with a large tan head, and a dark brwon with red tints. Aroma is filled with peaches, a ginger-like spice and some malt. The flavor was sweeter than I expected. Lots of cherry, peach and some cinnamon. This is too sweet for my tastes, like a few other Belgians.

Hazy red amber color with small head. Aroma is sweet and a little malty.Sweet caramel flavor that is very similiar to the trappist style. Alcohol seems stronger than 7.5.More complex than I thought it would be. A very nice Belgian ale.

Dark red, almost purple.  Aromas are bready yeast, fruity malts and brandy.  Flavours are just as rich - xmas pudding winter fruit laced with warming brandy.  The finish is licourice and spices.  Full of malty goodness (probably!).  Another good De Dolle.  It actually seems more complex than its already heady alcohol level.

The aroma is sweet malty with clear notes of yeast. The color is a hazy dark amber and it has a fine head. The flavor is malty and complex with caramel and yeast. The alcohol runs prickling over the tongue and gives it a good mouthfeel. A lovely beer.

bottle at 3.59 it's an amazing and very surprising ale.  the aroma is simply the best i've smelled in years.  Honey candied smell with a beautiful creamy head and a  mahogamy color and perfect carbonation.  I'm just impressed with this beer and would compare it to a trappist except that it's a little too sweet.  flavors of chocolate, licorice, brown sugar, and fruits were there.  slight crisp hop finish.  I do not believe that this beer is 7.5 percent alcohol.  In my opinion it felt like an 8.5 or even a 9%.  Do not pass this ale, truly an awesome belgian and a beautiful bottle as well.

hey i loved this stuff.  i think it's quite difficult to find.  had it in antwerp at a bar near the church and the train station.  think something like the rochefort 8.  more plummy chocolate flavor than the more typical belgian fruit flavors.  definitely worth a try and your attention

Dirty mahogany.  Aromas of deep roasted crystal malt, smoke and brown sugar.  Powerfully sweet carmel malt flavors with a touch of brown sugar.  Finished with some smoke, light hops and nutty malt flavors with an undeniable cloak of warming alcohol.  Just a bit too sweet for me.

Gorgeous deep dark rosey brown color thats nice and syrupy thick, a gigantor speckled marshmellowy thick head that looks a bit like pureed bananas sits tall and mighty. Its slower than slow to settle, if ya can call it that, it takes an awful long time to move, but once it stops it stops at just under a finger high and maintains a murky frappacchino crown the whole glass down. The lacing sticks all over the place in thick patchy curtains; the pinnacle of a great looking beer!

Aroma has a considerately yeast filled, softly spiced top with an underlying dulled dark citrus and tropical fruitiness with some banana, pear, and a bit of lemon. Alcohol presents itself at first as well but seems to dissapate as it warms where the yeasty spicyness really becomes dominate bringing out some gingerbread and corriander.

Fantastic structure of fairly strong and pleasant flavors with a super fine showmanship of soft, well rounded fruitiness up front bringing a small brigade of banana, lemon, red apple, and fig. Fairly smooth with a stable maltyness and calming fuzzy full roundness in the front. In the middle some soft caramel sneaks around the corners as it begins to fade off towards the finish the spices and yeast kick in with a bit of singe on the back of the throat and some hop bite adds some dryness floating off late with wood and spice. I really liked the way it starts soft and fruity and takes its time to build into the spicy finish, very nice.

Feel has a good fuzzy/fluffy carbonation and texture that comes across the whole way through. Has a bit of crispness and dryness in parts just before the finish, but mostly the malts surge in a gradual smoothness as it goes down with yeasty spices grabbing around the edges; considerably exquisite drinkability with this first-rate ale. Yum! I think I'll have another thank you.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 (Bottled) Very murky dark reddish brown color with a medium, beige head. Dried-fruity, slightly tart, vinous aroma with burned sugar, vanilla, and alcohol and anise hints. Sour-sweetish, raw-malty and dark-fruity flavor with some rhummy alcohol presence and a long, peppery-spicy licorice finish. Somewhat fizzy-foamy-carbonated, medium-bodied palate. A classic, but not the best from this great brewery.
(Bottled, 1986 vintage sampled in 2005) All carbonation gone, quite vinous/whiskeyish, pretty dry. Not at its best, but definitely interesting! Im not gonna score this one.

(Draught)The beer comes from the tap a bit hazy and a nice mahogany color with the head off white and frothy, the size modest and the lace a white veil upon the glass. Nose is citrus like, crisp and fresh with a sweet malt front, ripe fruit aroma also noticeable, peppery, coriander maybe, and a plethora of aromas for sure start is sweet, nicely malted and the top light to medium in its feel to the palate. Finish is prickly in its acidity, the hops dynamic in their bite, very dry aftertaste, a fine beer and one I will drink more off.

Dark amber with a big rocky off-white head. Musty aroma of raisin, plums, honey, spices and sweetened apples. Sweet and fruity flavour of cherries, plums, riped apples, raisins. Later the deep malty choclate flavours comes in with notes of burnt sugar. Some sour notes is there too. Long spicy finish. What a beer!
A very very interesting beer. A veritable rainbow of flavors that gets better the more you drink.  Very malty aroma escapes into the nose from the outset.  An enjoyable selection for the malt lover.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2004 Amber, foggy body.  Off-white, homogeneous head, mostly diminishing and fairly lacing.  Malty, coffee (branded) aroma.  Moderately sweet, lightly bitter initial flavour.  Coffee-flavours. Lightly bitter, ligthly sweet (long) finish.  Overwelming malty finish.  Very pleasant beer.
On tap--massive, rocky head that took a while to subside enough to drink this.  Dark amber color, dominated by malty aroma.  Hops difficult to find in here, but a tasty, sweetish brew.

11.2 oz capped bottle: murky orange body . . . firm, tightly bubbled light brown head.  Thick yeasty/estery aroma with warm dough, pineapple, caramel malt and moist cedar.  Full, juicy and tasty: grapes, spicy peaches, black cherries, buttered toast, anise, and an interesting mustiness.  The musty component is very similar to the Special Reserva 2002, but overall this one is more malty and full-flavoured, but less complex and the carbonation is not as lively.  A wonderful malty treat from De Dolle. . .

This brew smells dauntingly sweet and syrupy - heavy and some wintry fruits.  So I tasted it, and it's not quite like that in flavor.  Only semi-sweet flavor, somewhat woody and even spicy.  The carbonation is little bit too big for my personal taste, and it takes a little bit away from this one I think.

Reddish-brown pour, with a fluffy head and large floaties resembling fish food flakes - earthy, cellared aroma, with lots of spice, darker fruits and yeast - tongue tickling carbonation - flavor is exploding with complexity - candy apples, cherries, raisins, dates, plums - brown sugar, molassas, cinnamon, ginger - finish is spicy and crisp, but leaves a lingering maltiness - thank you sir, may I have another?

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 Bottle pours a burnt red orange with an off white head, good lace, and sediment that will not stay down.  The aroma is malty, yeasty, and fruity.  The flavor is fantastic:  slightly tart, sweet and malty, slightly earthy, yeasty and cheesy, spicy, peppery, a nice lingering spicy freshness on the tongue, and a slightly hopped flowery bitterness.  The palate is rich and smooth, but as with the other De Dolle products, very nicely carbonated.  Overall, this is very, very good.  I could drink this all the time.
(Bottle)  Pours orangish brown color with a thick frothy tan head.  Has a fruit and caramel aroma.  Flavors of caramel, fruit, and malt.  Great beer!

Bottled at the Brugse Beertje, Bruges, September 2003. This was about the tenth beer that I had in the Brugse Beertje, one of the great beer bars of Belgium, so all I can decipher from my notes is "a bit special". I will re-rate in a more sober state when I get the chance.  According to Tim Webb, the style has changed from a sour Flemish brown style to something more akin to an  abbey style beer . If you scroll through all the tasting notes, that change comes through quite clearly.
Dark hazy red color with a big tan head. Sweet fruity aroma. Very sweet and acidic, with sour fruit flavors.

Cloudy orangish brown color with a very large off-white head. Sweet malt, caramel, alcohol and a hint of clove in the aroma. Very rich sweet caramel, malt, alcohol, and pepper flavors. Extremely bubbly feel.

Cloudy, murky dark orangeish brown with a massive tan head. The aroma was full of licorice, toasted caramel, sweet alcohol, and some earthy tones. The flavor was very sweet...licorice, alcohol, earthy character...with a wicked peppery sting at the end. Very bubbly feel...more so than I like.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2006 What a cool brewery!! Oerbier has a medium head on a dark hazy amber colored body.  Aroma is fruity with liquorice and a quite heavy hint of alcohol. Flavors are roasted malt, tobacco, liquorice, nuts and yeast with an alcoholic finish. A good beer that feels stronger than it is!
Rerate after having had this on draught at the brewery in october 2005. This beer is freaking awesome. Full, vinous, tasty. Sitting at the cozy De Dolle bar with a piece of Oerbier pate and a glass of this is some of the closet you ever get to beer-heaven!

Deep amber hue with big frothy off-white head and very good lace. A lot of floaties due to my overaggressive pour. The aroma hints of ripe fruits, earthy and dusty yeast esters, aromatic hops, and toasted  caramel malts. The taste starts sweet but then a sour twang shows up to clean the palate, very nice! Woody and earthy aftertaste/ The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. A solid beer and unlike the Reserva. Recommended. Thanks MattA for the bottle.

Nice bouquet. Malts, brown or candy sugar, plums. Light spicy hops. Cloudy copper-brown with big foamy off-white lacing head. Heavy watery body with med-light carb. Great taste. Sweet throughout, especially to start. Brown sugar, alcohol, candied fig & vanilla. Finish is bitter & just right. Fruity vaporous & light bitter after but not cloying. This is a very good beer.

Deep caramel in colour.  Aroma was yeasty, some citrus, and candy apples.  Flavour was quite yeasty, malty, very spicy, peppery, with some candy cane as well.  Finish is smooth with a medium bitterness, some caramel.  This seems like it would be a huge beer but its only 7.5%  That's just outstanding.

Massive, undulating Belgian head and murky brown body. Aroma of baking soda, dates, and sweat, but good. Intense earthy flavor and organic sweetness. Has elements of figs, cherries, tobacco, leather, fruit peel, oranges, and lemony sourness. This is superb stuff.
At first a bit too much acid, a bit sour. After an hour the acidity is mostly gone, and the beer becomes real good, bread in aroma and flavor.
This is a thick beer you can see little bits and piece just floating around.  Nice brown color with a beautiful thick head.  A slight hint of flowers in its aroma. Not bad at all.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Cloudy amber brown with a massive off white head.  Very sweet fruity aroma full of raisin, plum, honey, caramel, coriander, pepper and clove. Medium creamy syrupy palate.  Very lively carbonation that dances on the tongue, and leaves my mouth tingling well after the finish.  Flavor is bittersweet and has notes of caramel, pear, pepper, clove, cinnamon, dark fruit and anise. Excellent!

Bright reddish appearance, well carbonated with excellent head formation. Sweet, fruity, jammy, cranberry, red wine aroma, some sugarry sweetness and an oakiness. Palate is a little more mellow than the nose and not as sweet as expected. Spritzy carbonation, dry prickly spice at first, suggestions of sweet sugarry fruits half way through, quickly giving way to a dry cutting finish.

Murky reddish brown with what seems to be the typical beautiful De Dolle head. The aroma is slightly woody, peppery, and yeasty. The flavor is sweet and oaky. Good plum and other fruity flavors. The body is tingly from the carbonation, alcohol is noticeable but not overwhelming. Another fine beer from De Dolle.

Brown colour when held away from the light, but when held up to a strong source, ruby amber sums up the appearance. Pours a dense light tan/off-white head comprised of large bubbles which eventually dissipate to a small head. Aroma of raisins, figs, malt, alcohol, cherries and a bit of caster sugar. Overall, pretty pleasing aroma and appearance! Medium-bodied; Super carbonated; Sweet fruity flavour with a strong amount of the yeast coming through and showing an alcoholic character as it mellows out. Drying character in the palate with some of the sweetness lingering and the carbonation still feeling a bit bubbly. A slight sourness is noticed near the ending sages of the beer, almost reminiscent of a green apple puckerness...but it goes away fairly quickly. Overall, a pretty nice beer, and I needed to drink this one before the Reserva, to have something to baseline from :-). I bought this 33 cL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York and sampled it on 10-December-2003.
Really enjoyable beer. If you can get it, get it. Very complex in flavor. Fruity aroma with a big fruity taste. Red in color. There is a very little alcohol burn when you drink it. Very good.
Brick red and yeast chunky. Tan head, lasting. Sharp fruity aroma, and nice. Big fruity malt, with a little alcohol burn in the background. A complex and enjoyable brew.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: My wife gave me a case to my 4oth birthday!  Bouquet is citrusy (lime?) on top of malt and alcohol.  Great brussels lace, but watch the sediment when pouring.  Never had an orange-y beer, but this might be it. Malt, citrus, and alcohol (in a good way).

The appearance was that of a large sized tan head that was smooth, creamy and frothy with fine-small sized bubbles that lasted for quite some time.The body had lively carbonation, yeasty and cloudy with an orangish hue.The nose consisted of alcohol, fruitiness, some licorice and malts.The flavor was that of some licorice, fruitiness and it also tasted sweet.The mouthfeel was smooth and it was medium bodied.This beer had excellent lacing.

This brew poured a very large head of envigorated foamy off-white colored long lasting bubbles that left behind an excellent lace and ayeasty carbonated hazy dark brown colored body.  The aroma was mild with notes of caramel malt and vinuous alcohol.  The mouthfeel was bubbly and tingly.  So tingly in fact it made my front teeth tingle.   The flavor was mostly of alcohol but also contained mild caramel malt and spices.  Half way through there were chunks of foam from the head still clining to my mug.  Although only 7.5% ABV it gave me alcohol shivers.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2003 (Draught) Yellowish head, fast gone; hazy chestnut colour. Very fruity nose, plums, grapes, dark & light malts, sweet and vinous both. Harsh bitter beginning, enormous hops of liquorice. Sweet underbuild, fruity, grape-like. Fruitiness culminates to the finish. Some alcoholburn; very full bodied. Better than just OK, but it still suffers from the yeast change, IMO. The harsh opening bitterness is new. Yet it remains a classic.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2003 Poured out of 11.6 oz. bottle, bought at Hi-Times Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA 10/21/03.  Ruby-copper red in color, clear body.  Very active with huge, uniform, frothy head that lingers.  Amazing amount of carbonation still boiling up from the bottom of the glass.  Nose is of sour and tart cherry, vinous and acidic.  Very estery.  A little bit vinegary.  Some mellowing sweetness and "roundness" to the scent.  Powerful, robust flavor, more malty with glowing (almost burning) but somehow sweet acidity.  Yeast also.  Vinous and lightly fruity on the front, but the malts control this thing.  Unbelievable long finish but a little overwhelming in its power.  Still leaving a nice hum and ring on the tongue many minutes after drinking.  Slightly oily texture on a thin body.  A ton of sediment sits in the bottom of the bottle, and when poured into the glass it naturally darkens the brew and muddies it up a bit (the irregular but large particles are all over the glass), but I really like the additional depth, dirtiness, and bitterness to the flavor.  Leaves a VERY oily finishing texture, with a film in the mouth and on the lips, almost greasy.  Overall, very fine stuff.

Aftering being let down by the BBB (Boring Brown Belgian) Chimay Bleu, I was pleasantly surprised by this delicious beer.  Oerbier is cloudy brown and poured with a thick, creamy off-white head and nice lacing.  I immediately noted caramel, cherries, raisins, and red wine in the very sweet nose.  Flavor was a rich medley of dark fruit, caramels and red wine, all of which formed a unique, very sweet beer.  Lively mouthfeel due to strong carbonation.  The sweetness does become a bit cloying by the end of the glass, however.  Still an excellent, most interesting brew.

Dark redish brown color with a big fluffy light brown head. Aroma is fruity and yeasty. Taste is sweet with some peppery spice. Malt flavors and some alcohol are noticed. Very slight tartness in the finish

UPDATED: APR 15, 2004 Head is large but quickly diminishes. Red-brown colour. Aroma; mostly fruity with some acidity and alcohol. Taste; powerful, plenty of malt, caramel, sirup, acidity, sharp, dry finish with some salt and pepper. A very nice beer with a lot of taste.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2003 Hazy brown sugar appearance with a huge head. The head doesn't want to leave, it wants to talk to me. I love how this beer looks. Smells like some sort of seasonal fruit bread. Tastes of alcohol and sweet peppery sugary fruit. The warmer it gets the creamier (like a pudding tease) it gets and the more it reminds me of that initial aroma I had. Delicious.  Thanks BierBauch!

Pours about the same color as maple syrup, but with more red.  Cloudy.  Aroma of brown sugar yeast, and spice. Flavor is sweet, almost like molasse (but not nearly as thick and overwelming) with dashes of pepper.  Finish is peppery.  I might have to cellar several of these guys.

pours dark mahogany with a head that lasts forever. No lacing though. aroma has light floral hops with fruit and strong alcohol presence. flavor has a brutal amount of alcohol detectable as well as some clove and citrus spice. Finishes with strong with a distinctive yeast character. not too bad.

Beautiful ruby red color with a large, frothy off white head, slightly cloudy and bubbly. Aroma is very sweet (candi sugar very evident), malty, with caramel, a hint of lemon, slighlty peppery. Flavor is sweet, rather carbonated, a touch of bitterness in the finish. Alcohol starts strong in the middle and remains thoughout the finish. A truly excelent brew.

Deep reddish-auburn, thick white, firm head.  Lots and lots of big, dark floaties.  Nose is strong and sweet, cola, malts, raisins, molasses, interesting.  Tastes strong, alcohol is noticeable at the end, finishes strong and sweet.  Starts a bit peachy, fruits get darker as it goes.  Lots of sugars, decent yeasty undertone.  Good full palate, strong yet quite drinkable.

The pour is a really nice dark red with slightly ruby highlights.  A very creamy head, that likes to stick around and show off its incredible lacing.  I was not quite sure waht to make of this one at first.  Has a really strong alchohol bite to it throughout, with some nice flavors that pop-up.  Figs and plums and some other dark fruits are dominant in the taste.  This is one that I am very sure would taste very good if it was aged in a dark cellar for several years.  Try it, highly recommended!

Pours a nice dark red with tons of lightly tanned head. Aroma is very sweet and fruity; pleasing. A nice sweet flavor reminiscent of plumbs. A smooth palate with a little bit of alcohol to finish it off. A tasty belgian. Just got it in the area, will be getting more!

A murky looking brown ale with a tan head which quickly settled down to a slight creamy dense head. The aroma is sweet, fruity and with a biscuit like aroma. Dates, plumbs and figs come to mind. Creamy mouthfeel and a medium to almost full body finishing with a slight warming sensation. Flavor is malty with a slight tart fruitiness. Overall a very good Belgian
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Hazy brown with some floaties, massive white head. Fruity aroma. Flavor was of malt and fruit. Dry finish with some alcohol burn. Pretty good.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2004 Sampled January 2004, USA
Pours a hazy amber-copper color, with a tan head that is made up of largish bubbles.  The first aroma I get is of some funky farm-house cheese.  This is followed by a sweet brandy-like fruitiness (plum perhaps), and some notes of alcohol.  The taste is sweet up front, but is followed immediately by a prickling carbonation that boils the beer on my tongue.  Quite fruity tasting with notes of plum, fig, and raisin.  A touch of acidity, though not nearly as much as in some of their examples of this beer.  There is a definite alcoholic kick in the finish.  There is a nice twang in the finish that gives this beer an appetizing character.  Some musty-earthy notes are detectable up front, and somehow this beer is quite austere/ vinous in character.  Overall this is quite good but I must say that I enjoy getting the bottles that have a bit more acidity in them.

Sampled March 2001, Belgium
Has a sharp fruity aroma.  It tastes nicely sweet with a caramel slightly bitter finish.  This is quite good, with a perfect amount of sourness & complexity.  When De Dolle is on they are quite good, even one of the best.  Unfortunately they can have bottles that are downright off, I am rating this for one of the good bottles, keep on dumping until you find a good one.

Huge amber orange color with a big off white head.  Was a bit too clear though, to my surprise.  Didnt have as strong of an aroma as I expected. Some warm peachy/orange alcohol notes and a bit of yeast.  Flavor opened up a little bit held back but then as it sat in my mouth it grew sweeter and maltier.  After trying Dulle Teve, this beer is not as flavorful, but also a nice comprimise with the abv.  Had alot of citrus notes blended with caramel malt which created a unique taste.  The flavor dried out heavily towards the finish.  Id say the dominant flavor in the medium-full body was raisin.  Tasted like raisins soaked in alcohol.  If I had never tried Dulle Teve this would have blown me away, but alas, my heart is taken by another. . .

Had from bottle on August 3, 2003What a head on this beer - poured maybe a 1/5th of a pint and it overflowed on me...once the head subsided, there was slight lacing with a nice brownish/orange coloring.  The beer itself has a quite interesting flavor - very spicy, very malty, very high on the alcohol meter.  The aftertaste is quite good - especially with the initial alcohol flavor you get when drinking.  Aroma is yeasty with a bit of citrus.  An enjoyable beer - a very good amount of alcohol and a great beer to drink on a cold night.

Pous a hazy, brownish colour with some suspended bits. Huge fizzy white head. Yeasty and sweet plum aroma. Flavour starts off yeasty but gas wonderful spices and a hind of citrus rind. Alcohol noticable at the end but not overpowering. Long lasting spicy aftertaste. Very nice
Hazy orange-brown with vigorous than head. Yeasty aroma. Yeasty flavor, slightly sweet with hints of orange. Somewhat syrupy, with the alcohol noticable at the end (like cough syrup).

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2006 Rerate, bottle aged about 2.5 years: Pours a murky mahogany with a large, frothy light-tan colored head.  Aroma has a nice, sweet bready Belgian malt and yeasty character with good milk chocolate notes.  Body has a nice full carbonation and viscous maltiness with dark caramel and bready flavors.  Mild, but enjoyable slightly oxidized malty complexity throughout and some earthy yeastiness.  Id say this has aged quite well.

Originally rated 7/16/2003: Dark brown with a large thick tan head.  Sweet Belgian malt and bready yeast aroma.  Body is full and bready with good sweetness and a hint of chocolate.  Finishes dry and warming.  A good Belgian strong ale.

A massive volcanic rocky tan head lasts a while atop an orange-brown hazy beer with lively carbonation. Streams of bubbles just keep coming from the depths....aroma of a caramel apple that was left in the basement for two-weeks. Oh this is nice, smooth as silk. Rich & complex with a wonderful balance of sweetness, tartness and bitterness. How could you not like this beer?

Cloudy copper with a humongous fizzy white head. Strong nose--cider, green apples, bitter orange, slight caramel sweetness. Flavor is quite sweet, with caramel and chocolate notes accented by plums, raisins. Has a dose of alcohol and a powerful bitterness, but it is overall very well balanced. An intense, awe-inspiring, full-bodied brew.

Broun and cloudy with a big resistant head.  Tremendous, sweet esters eminate from the beer.  Rich dense beltium character with chocolate and estery notes predominating.  Thiner than say...a rochefort 8.

Lots of head on this brew.Amber color.Fruity licorice aroma.I Still have mountains of foam.The taste is big on malt and the alcohol shines through very nicely,hoppy bitterness,with a definate alcohol feel to it the after taste is bitter with alcohol not bad but i know there are better BSA's out there.
Deep brown beer with a frothy head and a very alcoholic nose.  Very strong liquorice flavour, very alcoholic.  Overall a good strong Belgian ale.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2006 a very fine brew!! Malty and yeasty aroma, a very nice aftertaste, a bit malty. Very sweet to.. 
[re-rate 23.6.2006]
1983 vintage .. First of all, Im not jumping aboard some band wagon just because this is a vintage bottle and almost as old as myself, I didnt expect anything from this, and had no idea how it was stored during those 25 years. I did expect this to be a fun experience but I thought that it was certain that the bottle was bad or oxidiced. Boy was I wrong, poured this into a burgundy glass, and to my surprise it was still carbonated. Very delicate and small bubbles and a thin but firm tiny white head. Very dark, but not jet black. Ruby black would describe the color. Massive aroma of cherries when poured, some malts and tiny hints of spices. When it heated up the raisins shone through and  created a perfect balance, both in the aroma and the palate. I cant describe this enough, the best flemish sour I have tasted and propably now the best beer I have ever tasted. A unique and magnificent experience!

Oh dear god. This beer is very, very nice. 
Giving the right belgium taste. This is a wonderful brew.
Please get a bottle if you can get over one, and consume it slowly.

Hazy mohogany/brown w/ great lacing and head retention of the off white head.  Aroma is very malty and yeasty with plums and alcohol.  There is also a little spicyness and a light clove aroma and it seems to me like just a hint of rosey floral at the finish of the nose.  The flavor starts malty and a little spicy, but is very well balanced.  Plum fruit flavors and alcohol also appear and finishes on the dry side.  Aftertaste is malt and spice and very pleasant.  Higher carbonation probably lends to lighter than actual mouthfeel which is fairly light compared to alcohol content which is warming.  Very enjoyable beer, I wish I had more than one of these.

Glowing red/brown body topped with a medium large foamy head that slowly settled.  This seemed very spicy to me - full of cinnamon and other "christmas" flavors.  Also a lot of bread and big time "earthy" flavors.  Palate was on the fizzy side.  This is nice - I'd save a bottle for winter though.
Great Belgian ale. Complex brew.  Fruity, earthy, and yeasty flavors.  Finishes crisp and clean.  Recommended.

Brown colour, very good creamy head. Fruity aroma (peach and apricots). The flavour is pleasantly sweet with caramel, raisins, apricots, pineapple and apple traces. The finish is quite spicy and alcoholic. Great complexity but not perfectly balanced.

Cloudy red/brown coloured. Malts and spices (coriander) in the nose. Notes of alcahol, but not much. Flovour is complex and acidic. Malts, spices and fruity accents in the flavour. Wellbalanced. Slightly bitter in the aftertaste. Definately a good beer.

Dark, murky and mysterious; what is hidden under the thick muddy brown body and its snow-blanketed cap?  First an enormously fruity aroma entrances with pineapples and pears in syrup, cinnamon and cardamom helping to enliven the heady scent.  The flavor, fruity, sweet, slightly alcohol tinged, impresses a bit less; the surface is the greatest part of the appeal I'm afraid, but at the same time I believe there are more mysteries to be discovered in further bottles, as it finishes elegantly clean and soft with a hint of maple syrup.

This one has a dark, cloudy brown color with yeast particles floating in it. The head is oof-white, about an inch above the beer, and lingers for quite some time. It has a lovely aroma of apples and malts with a touch of yeastiness. Medium body with lots of carbonation, the flavor is malty with touches of plums and cherries. The finish is very fruity with hints of cherries and cranberries. Excellent!

Yet another from Lucky Baldwins.  A very nice looking brew consisting of a blood/brown color.  A dark cherry and cranberry flavor. Smelled about the same as it tasted.  Very nice brew If I do say so.  Maltiness comes thru, but is overshadowed by the fruit flavors.

Had this one poured from tap at Lucky Baldwins in Pasadena. Deep deep ruby red, blood color, with a small just off white head. The aroma was fruity, and malty. The taste gave way to a definite cranberrishness..licorice, malt, and other sweet fruits come to mind. Very active carbonation level in this one with a clean, dry malty palate cleansing finish. Some fruity malts left over in the aftertaste, but very pleasant overall.

Deep ruddy brown hue.  Off white head.  Big carbonation.  Nose of fruit, yeast.  Grapes, cherries, very sweet, medium bodied, very carbonated.  Sour and terribly drinkable.  Im impressed.  Finishes dry and acidic.  Yeasty and fruity, get some of this brew!

Pours with a dark, thick brown color below the thick, full light brown head.  The was aroma great.  Toffee, chocolate, plum, raisin and anise.  The flavor has wonderful balance of both sweetness and tart/sour characteristics.  This was something I could drink often.

Dark copper color with a plentitude of fish food on the bottom of the glass. A moderate light cream head.  Slightly vinous, and quite alcoholic and malty in aroma. Touch more floral in aroma is it warms.  Bitter sweet chocolate flavors along with caramel. Almost like having german sweet chocolate cake.

Orange,citrus wood sweet yeasty aromas.Dark chestnut appearance with white particles and a huge firm light tan head.Mild carbonation.Sweet,slightly tart,flavors of oak,anise,cherries and tropical fruit.Herbal dryish finish.
This was a VERY nice belgian strong. Good, bold flavor, with a nice aroma and color, too. Great beer!

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2005 Had a dry, almost nutty taste to it. Pours a dark brown but is hazy and is full of sediment. Taste reminds me of slight chocolate and licorice. Somewhat dry during the finish. Recommended.  (8, 3, 7, 3, 16)

Bottle. "Spec Brew 2005". Deep copper body. Almost ruby. Nose is dark fruits, yeast, banana liquor, sweet malts, light alcohol, mild tartness, and light alcohol. Taste has a mild sour fruit note and some nice tartness to it. Light alcohol, dark fruits, sweet malts, maybe light woodiness and caramel.  Pleasantly drinkable. Body is very effervescent and I would be let down if it werent, considering this is De Dolle. Mild alcohol warmth, and a medium overall feel. Finishes with sweet malts, light tart fruits, mild alcohol, caramel, dark fruits, and light cocoa. Very nice. Much better than I remember "regular" Oerbier being. (8, 4, 7, 4, 16).

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2003 Sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm.
Hazy, reddish brown. Woody nose. Dry and hoppy solidly malty. Peppery, rounded mouthfeel and some vinou qualities. Salty bitterish finish.
Old rating, bottled. 
Deep ruby and lively with rich, firm head. Vinuous nose. Sweet and lean with rich toffee flavour and some lactic acidity. The finish has notes of cherries and a short sting of bitter hops. Complex and really tasty. (9/5/8/4/16)

In a night of extreme indulgence (Westy12, Samichlaus...) The Oerbier held it's own. A bit like a brown ale but with a sharpness hard to place, perhaps from being a bit overcarbonated. The head is made up of larger than usual bubbles. Best to let it subside a bit. Subtle sourness. Nice malt character, very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003 Aroma of tofee/ caramel and plum/cherry notes. Malt is sweet, notes of dark fruit (especially cherry). Light chocolate malt flavor as well. Spicy, slightly sour but very smooth finish. Rich. Seems to exhibit a perfect amount of sourness to complement the complexities of the malt. Probably the best beer from DeDolle.
Malty sweet aroma.  Pours a nice amber color with quickly diminishing head.  Malt, fruit and sweet flavors. Alcohol is slightly noticeable. Perfect medium feel on the palate. Excellent beer.
Nice glass. Dark fruityness. Malty and slightly acidic. Complex.
Strong aroma of burnt raisins. Quite carbonated. Very complex and very delicious.

This beer rocks!
The aroma is malty, acrid and yeasty with notes of dark bread, caramel, herbs, spices, bananas, apples, alcohol and raisins. Yes, its a bit complex and very interesting.
Sparkling clear deep amber hue with a huge, creamy/rocky off-white head. Mostly lasting with excellent lacing.
The flavor is very malty, slightly sweet, tart and acidic up front. Tangy, acidic and modestly bitter with a warm alcohol presence on the backside.
Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Fizzy carbonation and a long, acidic, lightly pungent, dry finish. Damp fescue at the wee end. Great Belgian ale! A must try!

Poured a murky brown with a huge amount of sediment. What is it with De Dolle that the head on their brews gets bigger it seems as the beer sits. This one has the spicy yeasty nose of most belgians but with an in your face malt profile. Over carbonated in my opinion.Flavor has dark fruit and alcohol is very evident for 7.5%.
This is my kind of beer - big and aggressive. Starts with a spicy malty nose. Toffee, licorice and almonds are all present in the flavor. This is like a meal in a glass. Heavy and complex.
The tasteprofile on this beer is serious :-) Raisons and dates in the nose, brown body with a little head. Sour, licorice, toffee and almond like.
Reddish brown with huge off white head. Smoky citrus nose. Complex tart smoky malt palate

Interesting beer. Aroma and appearance are exceptional, with a huge sticky head that lasts until the end. Has an initial cotton candy flavor that melds with a sour cherry fruitiness and sweet malt backdrop. Alcohol is apparent and fades in and out and never really overides any of the flavors. A unique and well made brew. The label is a hoot as well. These guys must smoke crack in their spare time.  Hey.... isnt this the same exact thing Venom wrote???
Really, though, what the hell is up with this label? Drunk at Noon. God bless America. (Belgium,too!)

Opaque brown red with big tan head.  Aroma is peppery yeasty, with some alcohol detected.  Flavor is strong alcohol, with some spiciness.  I feel that if someone took a lighter to my mouth, Id spew fire.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2005 Rerate #2: Delicious beer. Very strong, high carbonation, so definitely not a session ale. Notes of a flemish sour ale, combined with a belgian strong ale. Beautiful stuff! Rerate: Dark color. Malty aroma, with notes of sharp licorice sourness. Roasted malts, sweet, fruity spicy also. Bitter palate, with alcohol present.

Original rate: Delicious aroma, of spices and malts combined. Bit like Abbaye des Rocs, but i only had that once. Bit sourness adds to the taste. Fruity elements also. Overall very good beer.

Deep, slightly cloudy Brown color with a thick creamy head.  Slightly sweet and spicy aroma with sour notes and an alcohol background. Spicy malt flavor with hoppy and alcoholic undertones and a hoppy finish.  Soda like on the tongue, full bodied and warming.

Beautiful autumn burnt orange color with sizeable head. First impression of this is the overabundance of carbonation, is similar to a homebrew fiasco I had not too far back. Very fruity: dates, plums, almost soury/sweet grape or cherry...is this the Belgian brewing sugar? There seems to be a lot of alchohol in the taste...dammit, there is so much more just floating below the alchohol but its hard to find. Some sort of piney, resiny sort of flavor seems to be coming through with the malt, but its hard to find under all of the fruit and alchohol.

Aroma has cream and cherry. Very full bodied. Yeasty flavor with cherry, some roasted malt and rosebuds. Hints of sourness. The first sip is not the best, but it gets just better and better and better...

UPDATED: APR 1, 2004 Dark amber, milky, with a medium creamy head. Slightly sour aroma. Fruity, spicy and I also note some whisky and raisins in the taste. Rerated: Slightly vintage. Wonderful mature spicy, sour sweetness. A very nice beer to save in your "bierkelder".
Dusty tree bark. Crude alcohol. Not very nice. Not very nice at all. Yugh!

Dark brown color, Very large head. Malty and rich. Robust flavor. Complex taste, nutty, nearly oakey. Somewhat vineous. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Interesting beer. Very complex taste. High alcohol content.
Nice appearance, quite dark, lots of bubbles, lasting head. Smell is sweetand malty. Taste is sweet (chocolate) and roasted in the beginning, complex palate, a little alcoholic perhaps.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2003 Served on draft in the proper three inch stemmed tulip.  World class aroma boasts passion fruit, juicy fruit gum, cherry, wood, mustiness, and spice.  Beautiful chocolate flavors intertwine with sweet chewy cherry malt.  Soft on the palate.  Surprisingly only a touch of acidity.  Most delicate, yet complex.  Like a Flanders red with chocolatey whispers.  A new favorite!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 18, 2005 Beige weak thin head. Dark amber color. Aroma is moderately malty with caramel, alcohol, ricolice and light wooden notes. Flavor is malty, sweet with banana, raisins and candy tones, ending in a  moderately fruity finish. Medium bodied.
quite spicy and with white grapes. fat and full and very tasty

UPDATED: APR 11, 2006 powerful. chocolate coated raisins, coffee, stacks of yeast, dried apricots. very smooth, rich, yet dry and complex in finish. a bit of gingerbread too. trailmix in a bottle. oh yeah rer8: well thats nearly 4 years since i last had this beer. and its still good. this bottle had notches for "houdbaar tot 10/2001" on the label, but "10% 2005" on the cap so have no idea how old that makes it, but its old. has spent 25 months under the house and its goin good. the usual amazing gigantic fluffy head that settles into a layer of almost widgetlike cream. beer is a clear magenta. aroma is lots of aromatic melanoidiny malt, toffee, some flowery/herbal noble hops of some variety, and a bit of medicine and phenol action. flavour wise a very complex blend of malt richness AND tart, dry hoppiness - not so much bitterness from the hops as just a herbal dryness. this is all supported by a slight sourness like in slightly underripe fruit. or dried apricots. a delicate chocolatey undertone sticks around with some warming alcohol. yummy. i have had some absolute motherfuckers of de dolle beers and some absolute stinkers. this one is one of the former.

Huge off-white head, reddish body, lots of floaties with some rising carbonation. I get mostly a malty aroma, but my allergies are acting up today. Complex flavors, noticeable alcohol in the mouth and through the finish. I liked the Ara Bier better, but this is pretty good.
If you like Rodenbach Grand Cru, youll like this.  Until recently the yeast was from Rodenbach.  Quite tart with lots of flavor.  Also check Ara Bier.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2015 Bottle (Sep 2014 bottling).

Head is initially huge, frothy/fizzy, off-white to light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium amber, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, toasted nuts), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of black cherry, cinnamon, candy sugar, orange zest.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

This beer has been a roller coaster over the last decade or so, reaching some low points that I hardly even recognized as Oerbier. But Im happy to find that this batch (Sep 14) is lovely. A bit too sweet to be 4+ for me, but very close.  Great nose...complex and difficult to articulate in words, but the black cherry note is prominent and very alluring.
Spicy but beautifully smooth. Poured with a massive head. Well developed taste and decent complexity.
First thing I noticed was that it was sour, and other then that it was a very good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2007 Bottled at Trappistenhuis, Ghent. Very dark brown coloured, beautiful big head. Complex nose of fruits, malts alcohol. Also fruity notes in flavour, obvious bitterness, dry in finish. Really nice. Probably ages pretty well too.
Smells like a red vinegar, but with a hint of cherries.  Nice dark color.  Something familiar about the taste - sour, grape flavor, like cherry wine.  Overall good beer.
I went with my bike to the Dolle Brouwers to buy this beer, and i have to say: it was worth it. Unique beer, fruity, a little cherry.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2015 My Bottom Line:
Red wine and cherry fruitiness meets wood, coniferous brettanomyces and berry jam in this super effervescent Belgian-style Strong Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sizeable head of foam covers the dark, reddish brown .
-Carbonation is overdone, rendering the mouthfeel rather explosive as soon as it hits the palate.
-Body is otherwise rather dry.
-The finish is barely acidic; this is more wild than tart.
-While this is enjoyable, it is also overrated to me. Too rough and unrefined on many fronts.

Bottles.
If you dont like the beer you got to love the label. The beer was reminicent of rodenbach with sour notes and  malty flavour. The palate is a bit up and down.

Murky dark brown colour with lighter sub-mm floaties and medium size medium lasting tan head. Celery, fruity nectar toffee sweet and fainter festive alcohol aromas. Big creamy smooth body with short port wine alcohol burst at start before the luscious bitter sweet chocolate and Xmas pudding flavours kick in. The lighter bitter/sweet alcohol finish is quite dry and at no stage is it too cloying. More suited as cockle warmer for cold wet winters than a warm July evening but still another winner from the mad brewers!
floral aroma, dark amber colour.Hugh fluffy head, fruity tatse.
Huge head in a bottle explodes in the glass - unusual tarty, malty, fruity with some licorice and brown sugar.
Nice little belgian ale, kind of rodenach-ish in aroma and taste, slightly sour malty flavour, but balance may be its fault, slightly mollassesy flavour, but the sourness bumps its mark up a bit.
Not the best example of a Belgian ale, IMHO.  The alcohol stands out, the head was excessive and there were black chunks of something (?) sitting on top of the head.  Flavor is overpowering.
Very flanders red-like in my opinion.  Some residual sweetness, shows plenty of alcohol.  Tasty, but I dont know if Ill revisit any time soon.

This beer belongs up there w. Belgiums best. Amazing aroma and flavor of apples, cherries, raisins, chocolate, with a tart refreshing finish. Pours with a nice creamy head. Nice cidery tart finish. Also a bit salty, but not a big flaw.

Really really tart...almost a Flanders Red? What beautiful brown hazy color, great body -- full yet light. My second fav De Dolle. What makes the bubbles so tiny in the head of this? Is it fruit? I recently saw this living breathing complex head on a blueberry stout, which is why I ask...Thanks Kevin.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: This is a tricky one! It tastet fine but I was quickly fed up with it because its quite cloying.
In the beginning very bitter, later on fruity. I bought this one in the brewery in Esen after riding 35 km by bike and it was worth it.

hazy amber orange color, ample hesad with delicate lace. pleasant aroma with cherries, green apple and caramel.
complex taste follows the aroma , the vherry flavor is strong enough that this could almost pass for a kriek.
sweet but with enough sour flavors to set up a fine balance

De Dolle Brouwers - The Mad Brewers. Oerbier (original beer was first brewed in brewer Kris Herteleers wash tub at home. Now, its brewed in an antiquated, cramped, old brewery purchased by the Herteleer brothers in 1980. Only info I could find was that its brewed with 5 malts and 2 hops (Belgian hops from Poperinge and East Kent Goldings). Appearance in glass is a rich, medium brown color, with a woody, fruity smell. Very fine carbonation bubbles with very little head. Taste is malty and tart, with a woodlike / fruitlike flavor (not as strong as a fruit beer though). Not overly sweet - excellent balance and feel. Very good.

Pour this one out realy gently. I always use a brandy type glass for rating and the head on this towered above the rim for a good five minutes before dropping down to a reasonable level. Aromas of raisins fruit cake dark malts yeast and woody vinous hints. Sweet malty body with a sourness like an old bruin. Not a bad sourness but more like the sweet tang of balsamic vinegar. Way too easy drinking for its strength.

Tangy and complex with a very thick head.  Superb, 
lasting palate.

Slightly hazy orange/amber with suspended particles throughout. Explosive head that will not die. Intense nose of malts and fruits. Huge flavors of malt, fruit,sugary sweetness and alcohol meld in a rich, robust and flavorful beer. Smoooth and warming and quite a treat. This is why we drink beer boys.
not very good, but I had it at the end of an intensive drinking eavening, so this could have clouded my judgement

Unfortunately, I drank this beer after a Lambic so it is hard to comment on its sourness.  However, its sweet full flavor with more than a hint of licorice is penetrated and dispelled by the alcohol leaving a nice balanced finish neither too sweet nor too sticky. Malt and cherry aroma.  Complex to an extreme, yet of an orderly fashion. My beer salesmans favorite, in my top ten.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2009 2009-11-26, bb 2008-06, at least 2 years old, 8-4-8-4-16=40Chestnut color; despite the age, it has too much carbonation, and the glass fills up completely with a huge head. It has a deep caramel aroma. Good body strength, with caramel and chocolate flavor; very light smoke; still pleasantly sweet; some oxidisation reveals its age. The bitterness is quite low, some of it deriving from the darker malts. Still good.2003-05-10, 7-5-9-5-16=42Beautiful red-amber color. The aroma is not so complex, it reminds me some whiskey, but the beer develops itself much more in the taste, with caramel, alcohol, malt, sweetness.Great one, must have it again!.

Aroma of bitter fruits.  Cloudy red coloration.  Not heavily sedimented.  Very nice lacing, slight head and carbonation.  Sweet/sour fruity maltiness, with some tartness as well.  Very intersting and unique.  Some hop flavors in the aftertaste, with the bittersweet fruitiness throughout.  Quite tasty indeed.
Amber, cloudy, very nice head. Aroma of vinegar and cherry; striking ! Slightly acid and sweet, very pleasant. Tart and long aftertaste.

Brown color, light brown irregular head, good lace. Sour start, light sweet, bitter, prune, laurel, hints of licorice, red wine. Sour dry mouthfeel and a little burn. Complex, yet in my opinion not completely balanced. Bottled, July 03, 4.0: Fruity apple and caramel aroma. Dark brown color, off-white firm head, good lace. Sweet, full, caramel, little acidic, lively, nice hop bitterness. Long lasting finish with a little burn.

Interesting beer. Aroma and appearance are exceptional, with a huge sticky head that lasts until the end. Has an initial cotton candy flavor that melds with a sour cherry fruitiness and sweet malt backdrop. Alcohol is apparent and fades in and out and never really overides any of the flavors. A unique and well made brew. The label is a hoot as well. These guys must smoke crack in their spare time.
Alcohol is very apparent, but mixes well with the strong malty taste and rich fruity flavor. Slightly fizzy on the tongue, great dark color, massive head.

Not a very memorable beer.  Deep, dark brown with a nice creamy head and dark fruit aroma.  Fizzy and malty, with a strong warming characteristic that coincides with the prevalent alcohol taste.  Medium-bodied with a weak nose, alcohol is the dominant feature.

It looks like theres tremendous variation in this beer. Im sorry I didnt note a bottle date because it seemed like I had an older bottle by comparison. Sour cherries and lemon with a resonant malty tang and plenty of sour across the tongue. Only a bit of residual sugars. Glaringly missing are any anise, sweet and stronger malt flavors. Some acetic acid and alcohol in the effervescence and a zippy tart finish with a vinous texture.  Something Id definitely like to resample.

Dark, hazy amber. Seems to be made in the style of a strong belgian brown in my opinion. Light head that disappears quickly. Sweet, coke-like aroma (sugars, lactose). Throw in a note of cinnamon also. THe taste was quite good. Very spicy and sweet with licorice undertones.

The longest-finishing beer that Ive ever tasted-- at least 15 seconds.
Tastes a bit like cider, but oh so much more complex.  The most
interesting beer money can buy.

This is one of my favourites!
Wet and strong!

A great beer.
A friend of me buys every year two palets.  One to drink, the other to stay in his cellar.  Because it seems that this beer becomes better with the years.  Imagine, it is already a very good one!
A bit over the top on my first try. A bit too sweet, but that does not say it is not great. I will revisit many times I think.
the best Ale EVER

Like Trois Pistoles, this beer is a mix between a Flanders red and an Abbey Dubbel; also like Trois Pistoles, it is a phenomenal beer.  It is both full-bodied and sharply sour, giving it a huge complexity as well as great drinkability. Another great beer from De Dolle.
One of the most amazing beers that ever was.
cloudy amber colour, fine lace, complex aroma: cherry, apple, slightly smoked; sweet flavor, great complex aftertaste (with a hint of cherry) - a monument !

Rich with a full malt palate and puckering
sourness that I find rather pleasant.
The sourness is very remiscient of sour cherries, 
and as Oakes mentioned, warrants comparison to a 
kriek lambic.  Cloudy dark brown color, as appropriate, 
with excellent creamy head and complete head retention.
High carbonation helps cut the sweet/sour flavors
and the beer on the whole is exceptionally drinkable.
Rich dark ale that can become quite lean and acidic with age, developing flavours remeniscent of Liefmans Kriek.
